Denmark was denied by Slovenia\u00b4s late leveler in a 1-1 draw also on Sunday. They meet in Frankfurt at the Waldstadion where kickoff is at 6 p.m. local time (1600 GMT). Here\u00b4s what to know about the match:\n\n- Denmark\u00b4s need for a win is greater, ahead of a final Group C game against a physically imposing Serbia team.\n\n- The teams renew their rivalry from a Euro 2020 semifinal played three years ago at Wembley Stadium. England won 2-1 after extra time, sealed when Harry Kane followed up his penalty being saved by Kasper Schmeichel to score when the ball rebounded to him.\n\n- Denmark did not easily forget how England got that decisive spot-kick, for a foul awarded against defender Joakim M\u00e6hle - \"a penalty which should not have been a penalty,\" coach Kasper Hjulmand said then.\n\n- There is a familiarity between the squads with teammates at Manchester United, Crystal Palace and Brentford on either side of this game.\n\n- Gareth Southgate is coaching England at his fourth tournament and will be less troubled than analysts and fans about the manner of victory over Serbia. England eased its way through the group stage at Euro 2020 - making at least two changes between each game - did not concede a goal, then accelerated through the knockout rounds.\n\nEngland's Jude Bellingham, left, celebrates with England's Trent Alexander-Arnold after scoring the opening goal during a Group C match between Serbia and England at the Euro 2024 soccer tournament in Gelsenkirchen, Germany, Sunday, June 16, 2024. Recent debutants Kobbie Mainoo and Adam Wharton are options.\n\n- England\u00b4s preferred left back Luke Shaw is still not involved in team training, and Kieran Trippier is set to continue on his less favored flank.\n\n- Denmark has reported no injury concerns.\n\n- A draw can be a good result for Denmark even if it ends the day third in the standings. Slovenia plays Serbia in the earlier game Thursday. In two previous Euros with a 24-team tournament format - which sends four of the six third-place teams to the knockout phase - a team with three draws has done enough to advance.\n\n- Another England win would set the team up to win Group C and face a third-place team in the round of 16. The group runner-up will face the Group A winner, likely Germany, in the vibrant Dortmund stadium.\n\n- However, England has never won two straight games to start a Euros tournament.\n\n- Defender Simon Kjaer was an unused substitute against Slovenia and his Denmark record of 132 national-team games is now just one ahead of Christian Eriksen, who scored in that 1-1 draw.\n\n- \"We see it every day in training here, and he\u00b4s such a nice guy as well. {"uri": "8187537051", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:25:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:25:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:24:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/sport/football/article-13551053/Woeful-England-Denmark-Gareth-Southgate-Euro-2024.html", "title": "Woeful England lacked fluency and cohesion in 1-1 draw with Denmark", "body": "Harry Kane gave England the lead before Morten Hjulmand superbly equalised\n\nThe good news is that England did not lose. The bad news is everything else.\n\nA 1-1 draw against Denmark edged them closer to the round of 16 but if they play anything like they played in the Waldstadion, that will be the limit of their participation in this European Championship.\n\nEngland were woeful in the sultry heat of early evening. They were outplayed almost from start to finish by the Danes. It is hard to think of a single player who emerged with credit.\n\nEngland were sloppy in possession, they lacked fluency, they lacked verve, they lacked confidence, they lacked cohesion. They looked clumsy and basic beside their technically accomplished opponents.\n\nTo add to that, Gareth Southgate's plan to play Trent Alexander-Arnold in midfield alongside Declan Rice appears to be in ruins. Alexander-Arnold is a quite brilliant passer of the ball but he has been largely ineffectual in an unfamiliar role.\n\nEngland were held to a 1-1 draw with Denmark which leaves them top of Group C as it stands\n\nIt was a disappointing performance from Gareth Southgate's men in their second group game\n\nSouthgate will need to be ruthless in his plans if the Three Lions are to roar again\n\nEngland are unbeaten in two games but it was an unconvincing display from the Three Lions\n\nPodcast All episodes LISTEN: What Jude Bellingham must do to elevate his game LISTEN: It's All Kicking Off at the Euros. Get the latest action daily EPISODE 91: Can Manchester City cope without Pep Guardiola? EPISODE 90: How Manchester United CAN win crunch FA Cup clash EPISODE 89: Why Manchester City aren't the reason the League is boring Play on Apple Spotify\n\nWhen Southgate withdrew him after 53 minutes here and replaced him with Conor Gallagher, it felt as if the England manager was cutting his losses. He was getting out before it was too late.\n\nMATCH FACTS\n\nDENMARK: (3-4-1-2) Schmeichel; Andersen, Christensen, Vestergaard; Maehle, Hjulmand (Norgaard 82), Hojbjerg, Kristiansen (Bah 57); Eriksen (Skov Olsen 82); Wind (Damsgaard 57), Hojlund (Poulsen 67)\n\nSubs not used: Hermansen (GK), Ronnow (GK); Kjaer, Jensen, Dolberg, Jorgensen, Dreyer, Kristensen, Bruun Larsen\n\nGoals: Hjulmand (34)\n\nBookings: Vestergaard (27), Maehle (73), Norgaard (87)\n\nCoach: Kasper Hjulmand\n\nENGLAND: (4-2-3-1) Pickford; Walker, Stones, Guehi, Trippier; Alexander-Arnold (Gallagher 54), Rice; Saka (Eze 69), Bellingham, Foden (Bowen 69); Kane (Watkins 69)\n\nSubs not used: Ramsdale (GK), Henderson (GK); Konsa, Dunk, Toney, Gordon, Gomez, Palmer, Wharton, Mainoo\n\nGoals: Kane (18)\n\nBookings: Gallagher (61)\n\nCoach: Gareth Southgate\n\nReferee: Artur Soares Dias (Portugal)\n\nVenue: Deutsche Bank Park (Frankfurt)\n\nAdvertisement\n\nWhether Alexander-Arnold starts another match in this tournament in midfield remains to be seen but Southgate was ruthless in the selection of his squad and it looks as if he will have to be ruthless here.\n\nIt was a fine plan in theory but it has not worked yet and tournaments do not provide time. Southgate acted because England were in danger of being overrun.\n\nNo one was safe last night. England skipper Harry Kane put England ahead but he was substituted in the second half, too. So was Bukayo Saka. So, too, Phil Foden, although Foden was perhaps England's best player. It was not a high bar.\n\nNow England have to gather themselves. They are top of Group C and even if they lose to Slovenia in their final game in Cologne, it is unlikely they will be eliminated. But that kind of talk is a far cry from the optimism that accompanied them when they flew to Germany.\n\nEngland had made an uncertain start. Alexander-Arnold was nutmegged in the first minute, Kyle Walker lost his footing over and over again and had to change his boots, and Kieran Trippier gave the ball away.\n\nBut after 13 minutes, England got their first glimpse of an opening. Walker, rebooted, slipped a pass inside to Foden and Foden span sharply, made space for himself in the box and then lifted his left-foot shot just too high. It was a welcome hint of the Foden we are used to.\n\nFive minutes later, England were ahead. Victor Kristiansen was so busy shepherding a ball away from Bukayo Saka on the Denmark left that he did not see Walker hurtling past him on his blind side.\n\nWalker stole the ball from him, advanced towards the goal-line and whipped a cross into the box. Saka prodded at it and it squirted loose to Kane, who had the simple task of sliding it low past Kasper Schmeichel into the bottom corner from a few yards out.\n\nBut Denmark remained undaunted. They continued to play the better football, they kept the ball better, they looked more confident and more fluid. Christian Eriksen was, as usual, at the core of everything they did.\n\nHarry Kane gave England the lead after 18 minutes to give his side the early advantage\n\nEngland's No 9 guides the ball into the bottom corner of the net after a well-worked move\n\nKane was sharpish to the ball as he pounced after it pinballed inside Denmark area\n\nKane celebrates scoring the opener while full-back Kieran Trippier (back) joins him\n\nMorten Hjulmand (No 21) celebrates after equalising with a long-range stunner\n\nWith no England player to pressure him, Hjulmand fires a shot at goal from 30 yards out\n\nHjulmand's shot strikes the base of Pickford's post before ricocheting into the net\n\nHjulmand (left) wheels away in celebration after levelling the scores in style for Denmark\n\nDenmark deserved an equaliser and ten minutes before half time, they got one. Kane received the ball under pressure at a throw in deep in England's half and hit the ball infield blindly.\n\nDenmark pounced on it and when it was moved straight to Morten Hjulmand 30 yards out, he took a touch and then let fly from 30 yards. The shot was beautifully and ferociously hit and it arrowed beyond Pickford's despairing dive and in off the goalkeeper's right-hand post.\n\nEngland were being outplayed. A minute before the interval, Hojlund held the ball up well on the edge of the England area and laid the ball back into the path of Pierre-Emile Hojbjerg whose curling shot was on target but well saved by Pickford.\n\nMany wondered if Southgate might withdraw Alexander-Arnold at half-time and accept that the experiment was not working.\n\nHe did not and Alexander-Arnold played one superb long ball over the top of the Denmark defence to Saka that Saka nodded over Schmeichel but into the side-netting.\n\nPhil Foden creates space to shoot but leans back too far and blasts his shot over the bar\n\nThe state of the pitch at the Frankfurt Arena came under huge criticism during the game\n\nDenmark piled the pressure on England towards the end of the first half after equalising\n\nBellingham (centre) is closed down by two Danish defenders during an England attack\n\nIt was Alexander-Arnold's last contribution. Eight minutes after the break, the fourth official raised the digital board and Alexander-Arnold's number was up. He was replaced by Conor Gallagher. It may be that he does not start another game in this tournament.\n\nREAD MORE Fans SLAM the state of 'absolutely s***' pitch for England's clash with Denmark\n\nEngland seemed to respond immediately. Foden danced through midfield and smashed a low drive past Schmeichel but it cannoned off the base of the post and Saka could not force home the rebound.\n\nSouthgate made more changes midway through the half. Foden gave way for Jarrod Bowen and Eberechi Eze and Ollie Watkins came on for Saka and Kane. England were still trying to wrest control of the match.\n\nBellingham produced one brilliant pass to free Watkins but Watkins delayed a fraction too long before shooting, the angle got tighter and his effort was well saved by Schmeichel.\n\nDenmark nearly snatched victory three times in the space of two minutes as the clock ticked down. Marc Guehi was sold short by a pass from Declan Rice and lost the ball to Alexander Bah but as Bah bore down on goal, Guehi recovered superbly and blocked his cross.\n\nSouthgate (left) decided to bring off Alexander-Arnold (No 8) in the 54th minute for Gallagher\n\nSaka battles for the ball as Schmeichel (right) rushes out of his goal to clear the danger\n\nAndreas Christensen should have scored from the resulting corner but he leaned back when the ball fell to him six yards out and his shot cleared the bar.\n\nAs England tried to play the ball out from the back, Walker gave it away and Hojbjerg curled a shot just wide of the post.\n\nSo England finished the game clinging on, grateful for a point. They left looking like beaten men. {"uri": "2024-06-395812804", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "11:21:19", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T11:21:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T11:21:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://thepeninsulaqatar.com/article/20/06/2024/england-faces-denmark-in-rematch-of-semifinal-last-time-decided-by-harry-kane-goal", "title": "England faces Denmark in rematch of semifinal last time decided by Harry Kane goal", "body": "Frankfurt, Germany: England faces Denmark on Thursday as the leader of Group C at the European Championship after a 1-0 win over Serbia. Denmark was denied by Slovenia's late leveler in a 1-1 draw also on Sunday. They meet in Frankfurt at the Waldstadion where kickoff is at 7pm Qatar time (1600 GMT). Here's what to know about the match:\n\nMatch facts - Denmark's need for a win is greater, ahead of a final Group C game against a physically imposing Serbia team.\n\n- The teams renew their rivalry from a Euro 2020 semifinal played three years ago at Wembley Stadium. England won 2-1 after extra time, sealed when Harry Kane followed up his penalty being saved by Kasper Schmeichel to score when the ball rebounded to him.\n\n- Denmark did not easily forget how England got that decisive spot-kick, for a foul awarded against defender Joakim M\u00e6hle - \"a penalty which should not have been a penalty,\" coach Kasper Hjulmand said then. Hjulmand said Wednesday he's not thinking about that incident anymore, preferring to look at the next game \"through the front window.\"\n\n- There is a familiarity between the squads with teammates at Manchester United, Crystal Palace and Brentford on either side of this game.\n\nTeam news - Gareth Southgate is coaching England at his fourth tournament and will be less troubled than analysts and fans about the manner of victory over Serbia. England eased its way through the group stage at Euro 2020 - making at least two changes between each game - did not concede a goal, then accelerated through the knockout rounds.\n\n- Southgate's main call could be if Trent Alexander-Arnold's long-range passing is retained in central midfield alongside Declan Rice. Recent debutants Kobbie Mainoo and Adam Wharton are options.\n\n- England's preferred left back Luke Shaw is still not involved in team training, and Kieran Trippier should continue on his less favored flank.\n\n- Denmark has reported no injury concerns with defender Simon Kjaer, its captain at Euro 2020, fit to return.\n\nBy the numbers - A draw can be a good result for Denmark even if it ends the day third in the standings. Slovenia plays Serbia in the earlier game Thursday. In two previous Euros with a 24-team tournament format - which sends four of the six third-place teams to the knockout phase - a team with three draws has done enough to advance.\n\n- Another England win would set the team up to win Group C and face a third-place team in the round of 16. The group runner-up will face the Group A winner, likely Germany, in the vibrant Dortmund stadium.\n\n- However, England has never won two straight games to start a Euros tournament.\n\n- Denmark's Kjaer was an unused substitute against Slovenia and his Denmark record of 132 national-team games is now just one ahead of Christian Eriksen, who scored in that 1-1 draw.\n\nWhat they're saying - \"We see it every day in training here, and he's such a nice guy as well. You know he has high standards that he sets and expects.\" - England midfielder Kobbie Mainoo, 19, on star teammate Jude Bellingham, who turns 21 next week.\n\n- \"Once the tournament starts you get into a rhythm. It came and we won it. So, we're confident now, we're happy.\" - England winger Bukayo Saka on winning the first game.\n\n- \"Are we favorites? No. Is it a failure if we don't win the Euros? No. But we have to have the dreams. If we don't dream, something is wrong.\" - Denmark coach Kasper Hjulmand.\n\n- \"English football has a great space in my heart. Maybe I am going to end there at some point.\" - Denmark goalkeeper Kasper Schmeichel, who won league and cup titles with Leicester and now plays in Belgium for Anderlecht.\n\n- \"He can produce magic at the drop of a hat,\" England defender Kyle Walker about Denmark's Eriksen, his former teammate at Tottenham.", "source": {"uri": "thepeninsulaqatar.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Despite the result, England retains the top spot with four points, while Denmark is second with two points.\n\nIt was a second successive lacklustre performance from Gareth Southgate's men, who squandered the chance to become the first England team to win their two opening games at a Euro tournament. The draw leaves the 2020 runners-up, previously touted as tournament favourites, at the top of Group C on four points, while Denmark are second on two after Slovenia's 1-1 draw with Serbia earlier.\n\nThe game got off to a sloppy start with wayward passes from both teams, quickly silencing the sea of red and white fans, a crowd that included the Prince of Wales and Denmark's King Frederik. But Kane -- who has now scored more goals at major tournaments than any other England player with 13 -- got England on the scoreboard in the 18th minute when Kyle Walker swooped in behind an unsuspecting Victor Kristiansen and fired in a cross that eventually fell to Kane.\n\nThe captain lunged and sent a left-footed shot from close range into the bottom left corner. The goal draws him level with Michael Owen and Wayne Rooney as the players to score for England at the most major tournaments, with four apiece. Denmark were the better team after that, however, and an equaliser felt inevitable.\n\nThe Danes capitalised on England's sloppy play in the 34th minute when Kane's pass up the field from a throw-in went to Kristiansen, who passed to Hjulmand. The 24-year-old launched a rocket from about 30 yards out that ricocheted off the left post and into the net. England keeper Jordan Pickford barely saw it coming, and waved a frustrated finger at his teammates.\n\nDenmark were the sharper team thereafter, as their midfielder Pierre-Emile Hojbjerg appeared to acknowledge afterwards. \"I would have traded it for three points,\" he said of his man of the match award. \"We played well, we played smart, annoying that we couldn't get one to go in. We have a lot we can take with us, we have to keep looking ahead and do it, we have time.\"\n\nLooking to inject some fresh legs and energy, Southgate took off Kane, Phil Foden, and Bukayo Saka with about 20 minutes to play and replaced them with Ollie Watkins, Jarrod Bowen, and Eberechi Eze. Both teams squandered chances, however, the narrowest miss coming from Foden, who rang a shot off the post in the second half in a far more lively performance from him on Thursday than in the Serbia {"uri": "8187629839", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:48:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:48:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:48:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/sport/football/article/3267431/euro-2024-england-held-denmark-1-1-after-hjulmand-stunner", "title": "England held by Denmark 1-1 after Hjulmand Euro 2024 stunner", "body": "Draw leaves the 2020 runners-up at the top of Group C on four points, while Denmark are second on two after Slovenia\u2019s 1-1 draw with Serbia earlier\n\nEngland must wait to secure a berth in the knockout stage of the Euro 2024 championship after a 1-1 draw with Denmark on Thursday, a game that Harry Kane brought to life with an early goal but which ended with his side clinging on for a single point.\n\nIt was a second successive lacklustre performance from Gareth Southgate\u2019s men, who squandered the chance to become the first England team to win their two opening games at a Euro tournament.\n\nThe draw leaves the 2020 runners-up at the top of Group C on four points, while Denmark are second on two after Slovenia\u2019s 1-1 draw with Serbia earlier.\n\n\u201cWe know we can improve,\u201d Kane said. \u201cI know there will probably be loads of noise and a bit of disappointment back home but we experienced this in the last Euros as well.\u201d\n\nThe game got off to a sloppy start with wayward passes from both teams, quickly silencing the sea of red and white fans, a crowd that included the Prince of Wales and Denmark\u2019s King Frederik.\n\nBut Kane, who has now scored more goals at major tournaments than any other England player with 13, got England on the scoreboard in the 18th minute when Kyle Walker swooped in to dispossess Victor Kristiansen and fired in a cross that eventually fell to Kane.\n\nThe captain lunged and sent a left-footed shot from close range into the bottom left corner. The goal draws him level with Michael Owen and Wayne Rooney as the players to score for England at the most major tournaments, with four apiece.\n\nDenmark were the better team after that, however, and an equaliser felt inevitable.\n\nThe Danes capitalised on England\u2019s sloppy play in the 34th minute when Kane\u2019s pass up the field from a throw-in went to Kristiansen, who passed to Morten Hjulmand. The 24-year-old launched a rocket that ricocheted off the left post and into the net.\n\n\u201cIt hasn\u2019t quite dawned on me yet \u2013 to score a goal for Denmark at a major finals is really, really big, so of course I\u2019m proud,\u201d Hjulmand said.\n\nDenmark\u2019s midfielder Pierre-Emile Hojbjerg felt his side should have won, however.\n\n\u201cI would have traded it for three points,\u201d he said of his man of the match award. \u201cWe played well, we played smart, annoying that we couldn\u2019t get one to go in. We have a lot we can take with us, we have to keep looking ahead and do it, we have time.\u201d\n\nLooking to inject some fresh legs and energy, Southgate took off Kane, Phil Foden and Bukayo Saka with about 20 minutes to play and replaced them with Ollie Watkins, Jarrod Bowen and Eberechi Eze.\n\nBoth teams squandered chances, however, the narrowest miss coming from Foden, who rang a shot off the post in the second half in a far more lively performance from him on Thursday than in the Serbia game.\n\nJude Bellingham, who scored England\u2019s lone goal in their 1-0 opening win against Serbia in a dazzling first-half performance, barely factored on Thursday against Denmark\u2019s physical midfield of Hojbjerg and Hjulmand.\n\nWithin a few minutes of the final whistle, the England fans had largely cleared out, while the Denmark end remained full of celebrating supporters.\n\n\u201cWe understand the supporters\u2019 frustration from the outside, but as a staff and a team we need to stay together,\u201d said England defender Kieran Trippier, who won his 50th cap. \u201cWe know as players we can take it up so many levels.\u201d\n\nEngland take on Slovenia in their final group game on Tuesday, while the Danes face Serbia on the same day, with all four teams still technically able to progress in the tournament.", "source": {"uri": "scmp.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8187631664", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:51:11", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:51:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:50:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6509804129600525, "url": "https://www.thejournal.ie/serbia-slovenia-euro-2024-2-6415393-Jun2024/", "title": "Hjulmand stunner sees lacklustre England held by Denmark", "body": "LAST UPDATE | 10 mins ago\n\nThe 42\n\nENGLAND FAILED TO guarantee their place in the knockout stages of Euro 2024 after Morten Hjulmand's spectacular strike earned Denmark a 1-1 draw on Thursday.\n\nA point was the least the Danes deserved as England again flattered to deceive in Frankfurt after an underwhelming 1-0 win over Serbia to open their tournament.\n\nHarry Kane had given the Three Lions an early lead as England pounced on a Danish defensive error.\n\nHjulmand's rocket from outside the box levelled before half-time and Denmark were left to rue missing late chances to secure a famous victory.\n\nEngland remain on top of Group C, two points clear of Slovenia, who they face in Cologne on Tuesday, and Denmark.\n\nSerbia's late equaliser in a 1-1 draw with Slovenia earlier on Thursday also keeps their destiny in their own hands.\n\nEngland boss Gareth Southgate said on Wednesday that he avoids media coverage during tournaments to escape negative stories, but will be braced for more criticism after another flat display from one of the pre-tournament favourites.\n\nDenmark's Morten Hjulmand celebrates after scoring. Alamy Stock Photo Alamy Stock Photo\n\nDenmark coach Kasper Hjulmand and goalkeeper Kasper Schmeichel claimed on the eve of the game they would not be fuelled by revenge for their Euro 2020 semi-final heartbreak to England three years ago.\n\nHowever, the Danes were a different beast from the side that disappointed at the 2022 World Cup and in drawing against Slovenia to open their tournament in Germany.\n\nDenmark had made the brighter start as both sides struggled to cope with a bobbly pitch in Frankfurt that cut up badly in just its second game of five at Euro 2024.\n\nYet, England capitalised on a howler from Hjulmand's men to take the lead on 18 minutes.\n\nVictor Kristiansen was caught unaware of Kyle Walker's run down the right and his deflected low cross fell perfectly for Kane to roll in his 13th goal at major tournaments.\n\nFailing to build on early 1-0 leads has been a consistent criticism of England under Southgate.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIn the 2018 World Cup semi-final and final of Euro 2020, Croatia and Italy were able to wrestle away momentum from the Three Lions.\n\nThis time Denmark were not deterred by conceding, although it took a spectacular strike to bring them level.\n\nHjulmand was given far too much room by the England midfield to take aim but he took full advantage form long range with a blistering shot that clipped the inside of the post on its way in.\n\nSouthgate made no changes at the break, but the future of his experiment of playing Liverpool right-back Trent Alexander-Arnold in a midfield role is in doubt after he was hooked for Conor Gallagher on 55 minutes.\n\nPhil Foden's form for England had been a source of much debate after he again failed to shine at international level against Serbia.\n\nThe Manchester City playmaker looked much more like the man that won Premier League player of the year awards this season and was inches away from restoring England's lead with a low drive that came crashing back off the post.\n\nSouthgate's caution has been criticised in the past, but he was bold with his changes in the search for a winner as Kane, Foden and Bukayo Saka were sacrificed for Eberechi Eze, Ollie Watkins and Jarrod Bowen.\n\nWatkins nearly made an immediate impact as he was denied by Schmeichel after a brilliant through ball from Jude Bellingham.\n\nYet, it was Denmark who had the better chances to take all three points in the closing stages.\n\nAndreas Christensen spooned over when unmarked from a corner before Pierre-Emile Hojbjerg curled inches wide.\n\nLuka Jovic celebrates his goal for Serbia. Alamy Stock Photo Alamy Stock Photo\n\nEarlier, Luka Jovic snatched a last-gasp equaliser for Serbia in a 1-1 draw with Slovenia.\n\nSlovenia looked on course for their first ever win at the tournament after Zan Karnicnik put them ahead in the second half, but Jovic headed in a corner in the fifth minute of stoppage time to haul Serbia level.\n\nSlovenia are on two points from two games in Group C going into their clash with England on Tuesday, while Serbia have one point ahead of their final match in the section against Denmark.\n\n- \u00a9 AFP 2024\n\nWritten by AFP and originally published on The 42 whose award-winning team produces original content that you won't find anywhere else: on GAA, League of Ireland, women's sport and boxing, as well as our game-changing rugby coverage, all with an Irish eye. That points tally always has been enough to advance in the 24-team Euros format.\n\nStill, England can finish in any position from first to third in the Group C standings after playing unbeaten Slovenia next Tuesday.\n\nSlovenia drew 1-1 with Serbia earlier Thursday, four days after getting the same result against Denmark. Serbia and Denmark also play Tuesday evening.\n\nSouthgate had defended his players from what seemed like unfair criticism for the nervy nature of the win against Serbia, ceding some control after Jude Bellingham's early goal.\n\nBellingham was subdued Thursday and Southgate removed the stellar strike trio of Kane, Phil Foden and Bukayo Saka in one sweep. Jarrod Bowen, Eberechi Eze, Ollie Watkins came on and within two minutes Watkins almost scored with a shot after a darting run.\n\nSouthgate looked flat-out furious in the 85th after England repeatedly gave away the ball and surrendered a series chances to Denmark.\n\nThe England coach barked at his players from the dugout with both index fingers pointing to his temples, urging them to think.\n\nEngland seized the lead on sleepiness in the Denmark defense. Hesitation by Victor Kristiansen let right-back Kyle Walker surge past him to steal the ball for a pass across the goalmouth.\n\nWhen the ball reached Kane he poked home a left-footed shot for a record extending 64th England goal for the captain.\n\nKane had his part in Denmark's leveler. His unwise pass out of defense soon went to Hjulmand, who strode forward to fire a low shot past goalkeeper Jordan Pickford and in the net off his right-hand post.\n\nThe game was played beneath a closed stadium roof on slippery turf that cut up after steady rain this week.\n\nThe teams had royal watchers from the stands with the king of Denmark, Frederik X, and future king of England, Prince {"uri": "8187504096", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "17:59:52", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T17:59:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T17:58:44Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6470588445663452, "url": "https://www.nytimes.com/athletic/5572865/2024/06/20/england-denmark-euro-analysis-kane/", "title": "The Briefing: England 1-1 Denmark - Kane scores but struggles, England drop deep, Hjulmand wonder goal", "body": "It was a familiar story for Gareth Southgate's England in their second game at Euro 2024, as they took the lead against Denmark before dropping deep and allowing their opponents back into the game.\n\nEngland started brightly and took the lead in the 18th minute through their captain Harry Kane, but after that they produced little. Denmark's influence grew and grew and they scored a deserved equaliser through Kasper Hjulmand after 34 minutes.\n\nThe result means England are top of Group C with four points from two games, ahead of their final match against Slovenia on June 25. Denmark are second in the group with two points, and play Serbia in their final game.\n\nJack Pitt-Brooke, Mark Carey, Dan Sheldon and James McNicholas analyse the key talking points from the game in Frankfurt...\n\nIn both England's games at Euro 2024, they have taken an early lead. Ordinarily a goal in the first 20 minutes would be expected to settle any nerves, and provide a platform on which to build for the rest of the game.\n\nInstead, England have responded to those early goals with lethargic passing, conservative positioning and a total abolition of offensive movement.\n\nFor the remainder of the first half, England seemed to have problems all through their spine. In midfield, Declan Rice and Trent Alexander-Arnold were pinned back on the edge of their penalty box. Ahead, Jude Bellingham and Declan Rice seemed to want to occupy all the same spaces. England looked ragged and out of ideas.\n\nA persistent criticism of Gareth Southgate has been England's inability to control games. Their ongoing inability to seize the initiative -- even when ahead -- will only lead to more scrutiny.\n\nJames McNicholas\n\nDespite the opening goal, this was not a classic Harry Kane performance.\n\nHe started the game in the best possible way, slotting in Walker's cross to put England 1-0 up in the 18th minute. It felt like an important goal for a man who has made a habit of starting the last two tournaments slowly before finding his best form during the knockout phase. That made this the first goal he had scored in a group stage since his hat-trick against Panama in Nizhny Novgorod almost six years ago.\n\nBut just as Kane was criticised for not doing enough in the build-up against Serbia, today he was criticised for not doing enough as a conventional No 9. He didn't press, didn't run in behind and never looked at 100 per cent.\n\nEven then it was still a surprise when he was replaced with over 20 minutes left for Ollie Watkins. He was carrying a back injury at the end of the season with Bayern Munich, and Southgate has been keen to protect him in tournaments before, so he doesn't always play 90 minutes.\n\nBut it certainly raises questions going into the Slovenia game, just as there have been in group stages before.\n\nJack Pitt-Brooke\n\nMorten Hjulmand's equaliser was struck from 30.9 metres out, making it the longest-range goal at the Euros since Mikkel Damsgard's goal -- for Denmark -- against England in 2021. As sloppy as England were in the build-up, it was an outstanding strike.\n\nThe 24-year-old Sporting CP midfielder has been linked with a move to Tottenham -- but Spurs' interest may hit a snag.\n\n\"My dad supported and we watched games together when we were younger,\" Hjulmand told Sporting's in-house television channel. \"When I started watching football, Arsenal had a fantastic team and Patrick Vieira was the captain and played in midfield. He was and is a great inspiration for me.\"\n\nIt's more than a casual attachment -- Hjulmand has the special crest which commemorates the 125th anniversary of Arsenal's formation tattooed on his left arm.\n\nJames McNicholas\n\nSouthgate made a triple substitution with just over 20 minutes remaining, bringing on Eberechi Eze for Bukayo Saka, Jarrod Bowen in place of Phil Foden and Ollie Watkins for Kane.\n\nBowen went wide right, Eze slotted in on the left and Watkins played through the middle.\n\nWatkins made a quick start, forcing the Denmark goalkeeper Kasper Schmeichel into tipping his shot out for a corner after Jude Bellingham's defence-splitting pass set the Aston Villa striker free.\n\nThe trio's pace and direct style of play gave Denmark something else to think about and, at times, they threatened to get in behind and stretch England's Group C opponents, only for a foul or misplaced pass to halt their progress.\n\nBut the main issue for Southgate's side, particularly in the final exchanges, is that they did not see enough of the ball. Denmark were far more comfortable in possession and at no point did they look troubled.\n\nConor Gallagher had replaced Trent Alexander-Arnold in the 54th minute and was quickly booked for a foul on Joakim Maehle. As always with the Chelsea midfielder, he wasn't short of energy but the change did not help England regain control of midfield and Denmark created chances in the final minutes.\n\nDan Sheldon\n\nThe positive take on England's right flank is that they do look dangerous in a lot of their attacking sequences worked down that side of the pitch.\n\nAgainst Serbia, it was Bukayo Saka's cross that led to Jude Bellingham's headed goal, and Kyle Walker's pace and overlapping run was crucial to England's opener against Denmark. There is the right balance on that side of the pitch, and Saka in particular looks to be having a strong start to the tournament in his first two games.\n\nEngland identified a weakness in Denmark's left side of defence and channelled a lot of their attack down that side, with 44 per cent of their attacking touches coming from the right flank. Across the two games, 12 crosses have been made for the right, with just four from the left. Unfortunately, that skew towards England's attack speaks to the negative take on proceedings -- that it is largely borne out of necessity.\n\nIt has been well-documented, but playing a right-footed Kieran Trippier at left-back is not going to offer that same overlapping threat -- or pace in wide areas -- and Phil Foden ahead of him is so much more of a ball-to-feet player who enjoys drifting inside and picking up pockets of space in tight areas. When opponents know that to be the case, they can adapt their own attacking game plan accordingly as England become predictable going forward.\n\nThe optimistic view is that England's right side of attack is looking strong. The pessimistic view is that their left flank is lacking the same pace and penetration.\n\nMark Carey\n\nIt took all of seven minutes for the pitch to show it wasn't quite up to scratch, with Denmark and England players slipping and sliding all over the place, most notably Kyle Walker who went down and took a significant chunk of grass with him.\n\nThe 34-year-old then jogged past the England dugout and signalled that he wanted a different pair of boots, realising there wasn't enough grip on the ones he was wearing.\n\nIt is not the first grass-related issue at this tournament either, with the pitch at Borussia Dortmund's Merkur-Spiel Arena needing to be relaid twice and then dig up and put down a third time after UEFA inspected it and said it was still unsatisfactory.\n\nAlthough the state of the pitch, which was last relaid in November, is a damaging reflection on the host venue, more alarmingly it is a risk to the players who could easily roll an ankle or injure themselves far more seriously as there is little to no support underfoot.", "source": {"uri": "nytimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The New York Times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "more@nytimes.com", "name": {"uri": "8185215909", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "11:33:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T11:33:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T11:32:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/sports-news-euro-2024-england-faces-denmark-in-rematch-of-semifinal-last-time-decided-by-harry-kane-goal-6049246.html", "title": "Sports News | Euro 2024: England Faces Denmark in Rematch of Semifinal Last Time Decided by Harry Kane Goal | LatestLY", "body": "Get latest articles and stories on Sports at LatestLY. England faces Denmark on Thursday as the leader of Group C at the European Championship after a 1-0 win over Serbia. Denmark was denied by Slovenia's late leveler in a 1-1 draw also on Sunday.\n\nFrankfurt, Jun 19 (AP) England faces Denmark on Thursday as the leader of Group C at the European Championship after a 1-0 win over Serbia. Denmark was denied by Slovenia's late leveler in a 1-1 draw also on Sunday.\n\nThey meet in Frankfurt at the Waldstadion where kickoff is at 6 pm local time (1600 GMT). Here's what to know about the match:\n\nAlso Read | IND vs AFG Dream11 Team Prediction, ICC T20 World Cup 2024 Super Eight: Tips and Suggestions To Pick Best Winning Fantasy Playing XI for India vs Afghanistan in Barbados.\n\nDenmark's need for a win is greater, ahead of a final Group C game against a physically imposing Serbia team.\n\nThe teams renew their rivalry from a Euro 2020 semifinal played three years ago at Wembley Stadium. England won 2-1 after extra time, sealed when Harry Kane followed up his penalty being saved by Kasper Schmeichel to score when the ball rebounded to him.\n\nAlso Read | Richard Kettleborough, Richard Illingworth To Officiate Blockbuster India vs Australia Super Eight Match in ICC T20 World Cup 2024.\n\nDenmark did not easily forget how England got that decisive spot-kick, for a foul awarded against defender Joakim M\u00e6hle -- \"a penalty which should not have been a penalty,\" coach Kasper Hjulmand said then.\n\nThere is a familiarity between the squads with teammates at Manchester United, Crystal Palace and Brentford on either side of this game.\n\nGareth Southgate is coaching England at his fourth tournament and will be less troubled than analysts and fans about the manner of victory over Serbia. England eased its way through the group stage at Euro 2020 -- making at least two changes between each game -- did not concede a goal, then accelerated through the knockout rounds.\n\nSouthgate's main call could be if Trent Alexander-Arnold's long-range passing is retained in central midfield alongside Declan Rice. Recent debutants Kobbie Mainoo and Adam Wharton are options.\n\nEngland's preferred left back Luke Shaw is still not involved in team training, and Kieran Trippier is set to continue on his less favored flank.\n\nDenmark has reported no injury concerns.\n\nA draw can be a good result for Denmark even if it ends the day third in the standings. Slovenia plays Serbia in the earlier game Thursday. In two previous Euros with a 24-team tournament format -- which sends four of the six third-place teams to the knockout phase -- a team with three draws has done enough to advance.\n\nAnother England win would set the team up to win Group C and face a third-place team in the round of 16. The group runner-up will face the Group A winner, likely Germany, in the vibrant Dortmund stadium.\n\nHowever, England has never won two straight games to start a Euros tournament.\n\nDefender Simon Kjaer was an unused substitute against Slovenia and his Denmark record of 132 national-team games is now just one ahead of Christian Eriksen, who scored in that 1-1 draw.\n\n\"We see it every day in training here, and he's such a nice guy as well. You know he has high standards that he sets and expects,\" said England midfielder Kobbie Mainoo, 19, on star teammate Jude Bellingham, who turns 21 next week.\n\n\"Once the tournament starts you get into a rhythm. It came and we won it. So, we're confident now, we're happy,\" said England winger Bukayo Saka on winning the first game\n\n\"We have it in our power to have a fantastic game against England where nobody expects us to win,\" Denmark coach Kasper Hjulmand said. AP", "source": {"uri": "latestly.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "LatestLY"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UEFA_European_Championship", "type": "wiki", "score": Jude Bellingham headed home the game's only goal amid a dominant start from the Three Lions, but they were eventually forced to hold onto all three points following a disappointing but stout second half showing.\n\nWhile England's defensive security should be commended, there's no doubt that they'll have to improve in possession if they are to overcome their fiercest competitors this summer.\n\nThese two last met on the big stage at Euro 2020 with a place in the final at stake. Denmark had enjoyed a magical run to the last four off the back of a near tragedy but were beaten after extra-time.\n\nKasper Hjulmand's side have their work cut out if they're to replicate their run from three years ago and their tournament started with a disappointing 1-1 draw against Slovenia. Denmark was denied by Slovenia's late leveler in a 1-1 draw also on Sunday. They meet in Frankfurt at the Waldstadion where kickoff is at 6 p.m. local time (1600 GMT). Here's what to know about the match:\n\nMatch facts\n\n-- Denmark's need for a win is greater, ahead of a final Group C game against a physically imposing Serbia team.\n\n-- The teams renew their rivalry from a Euro 2020 semifinal played three years ago at Wembley Stadium. England won 2-1 after extra time, sealed when Harry Kane followed up his penalty being saved by Kasper Schmeichel to score when the ball rebounded to him.\n\n-- Denmark did not easily forget how England got that decisive spot-kick, for a foul awarded against defender Joakim M\u00e6hle -- \"a penalty which should not have been a penalty,\" coach Kasper Hjulmand said then.\n\n-- Gareth Southgate is coaching England at his fourth tournament and will be less troubled than analysts and fans about the manner of victory over Serbia. England eased its way through the group stage at Euro 2020 -- making at least two changes between each game -- did not concede a goal, then accelerated through the knockout rounds.\n\n-- A draw can be a good result for Denmark even if it ends the day third in the standings. Slovenia plays Serbia in the earlier game Thursday. In two previous Euros with a 24-team tournament format -- which sends four of the six third-place teams to the knockout phase -- a team with three draws has done enough to advance.\n\n-- Another England win would set the team up to win Group C and face a third-place team in the round of 16. The group runner-up will face the Group A winner, likely Germany, in the vibrant Dortmund stadium.\n\n-- However, England has never won two straight games to start a Euros tournament.\n\n-- \"We see it every day in training here, and he's such a nice guy as well. You know he has high standards that he sets and expects.\" -- England midfielder Kobbie Mainoo, 19, on star teammate Jude Bellingham, who turns 21 next week\n\n-- \"Once the tournament starts you get into a rhythm. {"uri": "8187543639", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:30:29", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:30:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:29:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/hjulmand-strike-earns-denmark-draw-182344504.html", "title": "Hjulmand strike earns Denmark draw as England struggle after Kane opener", "body": "\"England, England, It's Never Coming Home.\" The chant from the Denmark support - to the tune of Yellow Submarine - had been heard outside the stadium in the hours before kick-off and it would reverberate around it during a highly stressful 90 minutes. On this evidence, it was the understatement of Euro 2024 so far.\n\nGareth Southgate can highlight the point, which moved England closer to the job done territory of qualification for the last 16. It must be said there is precious little jeopardy around that. Who exactly does not advance?\n\nRelated: Denmark 1-1 England: Euro 2024 - live reaction\n\nThe jeopardy was to be found in the England performance. They might have nicked the win, Phil Foden hitting a post in the second half; a few other assorted flickers. And, equally, they might have lost because Denmark had their chances. There was a last-ditch quality to some of England's defending and when Pierre-Emile H\u00f8jbjerg shaped a curler for the far corner in the 85 minute, England's hearts were in their mouths. The shot was off target.\n\nEngland lacked structure in midfield, progressive patterns, with all three of Southgate's starters here - Trent Alexander-Arnold, Declan Rice and Jude Bellingham - enduring difficult games. The manager raised eyebrows when he withdrew his front three of Bukayo Saka, Harry Kane and Foden on 70 minutes, although Jarrod Bowen, Ollie Watkins and Eberechi Eze did bring something in their places.\n\nFor England, the control was not there. The hope had been when Kane put them ahead that they could settle but they did not. There was a frenetic feel to the occasion and Denmark were good value for the draw, secured by Morten Hjulmand's scorching 30-yard drive just after the half hour.\n\nFollowing the 1-0 win over Serbia on Sunday, which had featured a second-half retreat, this was a backwards step for England. The hope remains that they can put their problems behind them and grow into a tournament that they started as one of the favourites. Who was buying that here?\n\nSouthgate had wanted to play better than against Serbia, although that did not apply to the opening 30 minutes of that game when England passed and moved sharply. The idea was to make another assured start with the same XI, Southgate keeping the faith, seeking to finesse the tournament bonds.\n\nIt did not happen. The truth was that England were ragged at the outset, making errors, too many loose passes. There was a lack of cohesion when it mattered on the ball while it also looked as though a few of Southgate's players had problems with the turf, which cut up badly.\n\nKyle Walker was one of them, slipping over twice, rolling his ankle on the second occasion, which looked bad. Fortunately he was able to continue, changing his boots before he re-entered. Walker would be key to the move for the breakthrough goal.\n\nQuite how Victor Kristiansen, the Denmark left wing-back, was unaware of Walker stealing up on his outside was a mystery. Maybe it was because shouts from teammates amid the remorseless din under the closed roof of his excellent stadium were impossible.\n\nBut Kristiansen did not see him as he pondered a backpass and, when Walker robbed him, England felt the surge of possibility. Their luck was in, Walker's low cross, seemingly intended for Foden, deflecting first off Jannik Vestergaard and then Andreas Christensen to break perfectly for Kane. It was a done deal at that point.\n\nDenmark did not panic. They had given up a couple of flickers at 0-0, Foden slipping away from H\u00f8jberg after a Walker cut-back only to shoot wildly; Kane seeing a shot blocked after Rice had won the ball high up. But it was Denmark who looked the more joined up in the first half, more dangerous.\n\nIt was worrying to see how much space they were able to enjoy in between the lines, England's midfield looking open against the ball. Denmark pushed, England forced to defend with a degree of desperation.\n\nThere were an alarming number of situations where England had no options on the ball and Kane was guilty of trying to force a crossfield pass from tight on the left inside his own half on the Denmark equaliser. It went straight to Kristiansen and when he moved it to Hjulmand, he detonated his rocket, watching the ball glance in off Jordan Pickford's right-hand spot. The power and precision were extraordinary.\n\nFoden would slice past a couple of challengers on 41 minutes only to ignore Kane and shoot weakly and England were the happier to hear the half-time whistle. Hjulmand had found room around the edge of the England area - his shot was blocked - while H\u00f8jbjerg shot too close to Pickford.\n\nSouthgate made a move on 54 minutes, introducing Conor Gallagher for Alexander-Arnold, whose performance will deepen the debate about the balance of the England midfield with him in it. Before Alexander-Arnold went off, he had pumped a long ball forward for Saka, which the winger almost made something of, waiting for the bounce and looping a header just off target.\n\nEngland sought greater intensity, Gallagher helping, although he would tread a fine line after being booked for a stamp on Christensen. Foden almost gave them the lead with his best moment, a couple of touches followed by a rasping low drive from distance that rattled the upright.\n\nSouthgate made his triple change and Watkins would almost get in onto a Bellingham pass. The closing stages were frantic, Marc Gu\u00e9hi robbed by the substitute, Alexander Bah, after a bad Rice pass but racing back to make a crucial tackle. At one point he blamed Bellingham for not offering an option, but Rice needs to look closer to home. You can't blame the player, he's not a midfielder! He was hooked after 54 minutes after a performance in which he gave the ball away far too often and went AWOL as Denmark took control. His head was clearly gone after half-time.\n\nRead More James McClean hits out at Declan Rice again as he criticises the England midfielder's performance\n\nBukayo Saka 5\n\nNowhere near the level of danger he posed against Serbia. He did not play badly, but nor did he do much good. With plenty of alternatives in wide areas, he has to do more than this. Like others, his energy in the press to disturb the Danes was not there.\n\nJude Bellingham 5\n\nFrom Roy of the Rovers to Doncaster Rovers, the man-of-the-match from Serbia was a shadow of the star from Sunday. He didn't win his duels and was all too rarely on the ball. When he did have it he kept onto it for too long and did not populate the box like he did in the opening game. He did well not to be substituted.\n\nJude Bellingham (pictured) failed to live up to his Man of the Match display against Serbia\n\nBukayo Saka (centre) lacked energy in the press and failed to show the same level of attacking threat he had shown against Serbia\n\nPhil Foden (centre) had good moments but again looked uncomfortable on the left wing\n\nPhil Foden 6\n\nOut of position on the left wing, again, every time he impacted it was when drifting inside, at times even right of centre in midfield. He had good moments, two good runs followed by poor finishes and another when he cracked post, but he cannot continue in a position he does not want to play. It's detrimental to the team.\n\nHarry Kane 4.5\n\nRight place to pounce for opener but then gifted possession to Danes for equaliser with baffling cross-field ball - he did not look where it was going. {"uri": "8187337047", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "15:53:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T15:53:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T15:53:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.nzherald.co.nz/sport/football/england-vs-denmark-euro-2024-live-updates/MFY4IUDRQRGXNGGFYWJH2EVLCU/", "title": "England vs Denmark", "body": "England and Denmark meet in Group C at the European Championships in Frankfurt.\n\n-- Denmark's need for a win is greater, ahead of a final Group C game against a physically imposing Serbia team.\n\n-- The teams renew their rivalry from a Euro 2020 semifinal played three years ago at Wembley Stadium. England won 2-1 after extra time, sealed when Harry Kane followed up his penalty being saved by Kasper Schmeichel to score when the ball rebounded to him.\n\n-- Denmark did not easily forget how England got that decisive spot-kick, for a foul awarded against defender Joakim M\u00e6hle -- \"a penalty which should not have been a penalty,\" coach Kasper Hjulmand said then. Hjulmand said Wednesday he's not thinking about that incident anymore, preferring to look at the next game \"through the front window.\"\n\n-- There is a familiarity between the squads with teammates at Manchester United, Crystal Palace and Brentford on either side of this game.\n\n-- Gareth Southgate is coaching England at his fourth tournament and will be less troubled than analysts and fans about the manner of victory over Serbia. England eased its way through the group stage at Euro 2020 -- making at least two changes between each game -- did not concede a goal, then accelerated through the knockout rounds.\n\n-- Southgate's main call could be if Trent Alexander-Arnold's long-range passing is retained in central midfield alongside Declan Rice. Recent debutants Kobbie Mainoo and Adam Wharton are options.\n\n-- England's preferred left back Luke Shaw is still not involved in team training, and Kieran Trippier should continue on his less favored flank.\n\n-- Denmark has reported no injury concerns with defender Simon Kjaer, its captain at Euro 2020, fit to return.\n\n-- A draw can be a good result for Denmark even if it ends the day third in the standings. Slovenia plays Serbia in the earlier game Thursday. In two previous Euros with a 24-team tournament format -- which sends four of the six third-place teams to the knockout phase -- a team with three draws has done enough to advance.\n\n-- Another England win would set the team up to win Group C and face a third-place team in the round of 16. The group runner-up will face the Group A winner, likely Germany, in the vibrant Dortmund stadium.\n\n-- However, England has never won two straight games to start a Euros tournament.\n\n-- Denmark's Kjaer was an unused substitute against Slovenia and his Denmark record of 132 national-team games is now just one ahead of Christian Eriksen, who scored in that 1-1 draw.\n\n-- \"We see it every day in training here, and he's such a nice guy as well. You know he has high standards that he sets and expects.\" -- England midfielder Kobbie Mainoo, 19, on star teammate Jude Bellingham, who turns 21 next week.\n\n-- \"Once the tournament starts you get into a rhythm. It came and we won it. So, we're confident now, we're happy.\" -- England winger Bukayo Saka on winning the first game.\n\n-- \"Are we favorites? No. Is it a failure if we don't win the Euros? No. But we have to have the dreams. If we don't dream, something is wrong.\" -- Denmark coach Kasper Hjulmand.\n\n-- \"English football has a great space in my heart. Maybe I am going to end there at some point.\" -- Denmark goalkeeper Kasper Schmeichel, who won league and cup titles with Leicester and now plays in Belgium for Anderlecht.\n\n-- \"He can produce {"uri": "8187554321", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:45:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:45:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:38:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.onmanorama.com/sports/football/2024/06/20/euro-2024-denmark-rally-to-hold-england.html", "title": "Euro 2024: Denmark rally to hold England", "body": "Frankfurt: England must wait to secure a berth in the knockout stage of the European Championship after a 1-1 draw with Denmark on Thursday, a game that Harry Kane brought to life with an early goal but which ended with the Three Lions clinging on for a single point.\n\nIt was a second successive lacklustre performance from Gareth Southgate's men, who squandered the chance to become the first England team to win their two opening games at a Euro tournament.\n\nThe draw leaves the 2020 runners-up, previously touted as tournament favourites, at the top of Group C on four points, while Denmark are second on two after Slovenia's 1-1 draw with Serbia earlier.\n\nThe game got off to a sloppy start with wayward passes from both teams, quickly silencing the sea of red and white fans, a crowd that included the Prince of Wales and Denmark's King Frederik.\n\nBut Kane -- who has now scored more goals at major tournaments than any other England player with 13 -- got England on the scoreboard in the 18th minute when Kyle Walker swooped in behind an unsuspecting Victor Kristiansen and fired in a cross that eventually fell to Kane.\n\nThe captain lunged and sent a left-footed shot from close range into the bottom left corner. The goal draws him level with Michael Owen and Wayne Rooney as the players to score for England at the most major tournaments, with four apiece.\n\nDenmark were the better team after that, however, and an equaliser felt inevitable. The Danes capitalised on England's sloppy play in the 34th minute when Kane's pass up the field from a throw-in went to Kristiansen, who passed to Hjulmand. The 24-year-old launched a rocket from about 30 yards out that ricocheted off the left post and into the net.\n\nEngland keeper Jordan Pickford barely saw it coming, and waved a frustrated finger at his teammates.\n\nDenmark were the sharper team thereafter, as their midfielder Pierre-Emile Hojbjerg appeared to acknowledge afterwards.\n\n\"I would have traded it for three points,\" he said of his man of the match award. \"We played well, we played smart, annoying that we couldn't get one to go in. We have a lot we can take with us, we have to keep looking ahead and do it, we have time.\"\n\nLooking to inject some fresh legs and energy, Southgate took off Kane, Phil Foden and Bukayo Saka with about 20 minutes to play and replaced them with Ollie Watkins, Jarrod Bowen and Eberechi Eze.\n\nBoth teams squandered chances, however, the narrowest miss coming from Foden, who rang a shot off the post in the second half in a far more lively performance from him on Thursday than in the Serbia game.\n\nJude Bellingham, who scored England's lone goal in their 1-0 opening win against Serbia in a dazzling first-half performance, barely factored on Thursday.\n\nThe Frankfurt Arena turf, which drew complaints after an earlier game, was no help to either team and was eventually torn to shreds. England's Walker had to change his boots early on after sliding on it and rolling his ankle.\n\nEngland take on Slovenia in their final group game on Tuesday, while the Danes take on Serbia on the same day, with all four teams still technically able to progress in the tournament depending on the results.", "source": {"uri": "onmanorama.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "OnManorama"}, That points tally always has been enough to advance in the 24-team Euros format.\n\nStill, England can finish in any position from first to third in the Group C standings after playing unbeaten Slovenia next Tuesday.\n\nSlovenia drew 1-1 with Serbia earlier Thursday, four days after getting the same result against Denmark. {"uri": "2024-06-393619380", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-18", "time": "14:50:45", "dateTime": "2024-06-18T14:50:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-18T14:48:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://amp.sportsmole.co.uk/football/england/euro-2024/head-to-head/denmark-vs-england-head-to-head-record-and-past-meetings_546197.html", "title": "Denmark vs. England: Head-to-head record and past meetings", "body": "Ahead of Thursday's Euro 2024 clash between Denmark and England, Sports Mole looks at the head-to-head record and previous meetings between the two clubs.\n\nyou have updates\n\nDeutsche Bank Park in Frankfurt will stage an intriguing Euro 2024 Group C clash between Denmark and England on Thursday evening.\n\nGareth Southgate's men kick-started their group-stage campaign with a slender 1-0 victory over Serbia on Sunday, a few hours after Denmark were forced to settle for a 1-1 draw with Slovenia.\n\nSeparated by 17 places in the current FIFA World Rankings, Denmark and England have butted heads in many memorable meetings in multiple international competitions over the years.\n\nHere, Sports Mole takes an in-depth look at the head-to-head record and previous meetings between the two nations.\n\nHead-to-head record\n\nPrevious meetings: 22\n\nDenmark wins: 4\n\nDraws: 5\n\nEngland wins: 13\n\nDenmark and England have played each other a total of 22 times across all competitive and non-competitive fixtures. While the Three Lions have come out on top 13 times, Denmark have registered just four victories, with the remaining five games all ending as a draw.\n\nThe very first meeting between these two European nations took place back in September 1948 when they played out a goalless friendly stalemate at a neutral venue in Norway.\n\nEight years later, Denmark and England locked horns for their first competitive encounter in World Cup qualifying, with the Three Lions following up a 5-2 home victory with a 4-1 success in the reverse fixture five months later.\n\nThose two victories were part of a six-match winning streak for England against Denmark, but the latter eventually celebrated their first triumph over the Three Lions in September 1983, with Allan Simonsen's first-half penalty securing a narrow 1-0 win at Wembley Stadium in European Championship qualifying.\n\nDenmark and England shared the spoils in a 0-0 draw during the group stage of Euro 1992, a competition the Danes famously triumphed in having qualified only after Yugoslavia were barred due to the developing Balkan crisis.\n\nSince the turn of the century, England have won four of their eight meetings with Denmark, including a comfortable 3-0 victory in the last 16 of the 2002 World Cup, courtesy of a Thomas Sorensen own goals and strikes from Michael Owen and Emile Heskey.\n\nDenmark got their revenge, though, with two friendly wins by an aggregate score of 7-3 between 2003 and 2005, before England matches that with two friendly victories of their own in 2011 (2-1) and 2014 (1-0).\n\nThe most recent three meetings between these two nations have all been competitive ones, including back-to-back encounters in the UEFA Nations League, with Denmark holding England to a 0-0 draw on home soil in September 2020 before securing a narrow 1-0 away victory at Wembley 13 months later, thanks to a first-half penalty from Christian Eriksen.\n\nEngland and Denmark last locked horns in the semi-finals of Euro 2020, with the Three Lions edging through to their first major tournament final for 55 years after claiming a 2-1 win after extra time at Wembley. Mikkel Damsgaard's superb free-kick was cancelled out by an unfortunate Simon Kjaer own goal, before Harry Kane slotted home the match-winner in the 104th minute after having his initially penalty saved by Kasper Schmeichel.\n\nPrevious 10 meetings\n\nJul 07, 2021: England 2-1 Denmark (Euro 2020 Semi-Finals)\n\nOct 14, 2020: England 0-1 Denmark (UEFA Nations League League A)\n\nSep 08, 2020: Denmark 0-0 England (UEFA Nations League League A)\n\nMar 05, 2014: England 1-0 Denmark (International Friendly)\n\nFeb 9, 2011: Denmark 1-1 England (International Friendly)\n\nAug 17, 2005: Denmark 4-1 England (International Friendly)\n\nNov 16, 2003: England 2-3 Yugoslavia (International Friendly)\n\nJune 15, 2002: Denmark 0-3 England (World Cup Last-16)\n\nMar 9, 1994: England 1-0 Denmark (International Friendly)\n\nJune 11, 1992: Denmark 0-0 England (Euro 1992 Group Stage)\n\nbody check tags ::", "source": {"uri": "amp.sportsmole.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8187592449", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:13:30", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:13:30Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:12:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.khaleejtimes.com/sports/football/euro-2024-well-get-there-says-kane-after-england-splutter-in-denmark-draw", "title": "Euro 2024: We'll get there, says Kane after England splutter in Denmark draw", "body": "England forward Harry Kane acknowledges the crowd after the match. -- AFP\n\nHarry Kane insisted England will find the right formula for Euro 2024 success despite their lacklustre display in Thursday's 1-1 draw against Denmark.\n\nGareth Southgate's side would have qualified for the last 16 as Group C winners if they had defeated the Danes in Frankfurt.\n\nEngland captain Kane gave them the perfect start with a clinical close-range finish from Kyle Walker's deflected cross in the 18th minute.\n\nBut England lost their momentum after that and Denmark drew level after 34 minutes when Morten Hjulmand blasted a superb 30-yard drive past Jordan Pickford.\n\nIt was hardly the kind of display that will strike fear into England's rivals, with the incoherent effort coming after they were fortunate to escape with a 1-0 win against Serbia in their group opener last weekend.\n\nBut Bayern Munich striker Kane is adamant England will eventually fire on all cylinders.\n\n\"I think we said before the tournament there's no easy games and I think that's showing,\" he said.\n\n\"We've got levels we can reach and we can be better both "Five things we learned from England's 1-1 draw against Denmark at Euro 2024, Arsenal star impresses again but Man City ace struggles", "body": "England drew 1-1 against Denmark in Germany in their second game of the European Championships at the Frankfurt Arena.\n\nGareth Southgate's side struck first in the first half thanks to a tap in from Harry Kane, for his first goal at this summer's competition.\n\nDenmark, however, weren't giving up without a fight and struck 35 minutes into the game through a stunning goal from Morten Hjulmand.\n\nAfter England switched off for a second, the Sporting Lisbon midfielder struck a beauty from 30 yards out which went in off the post.\n\nIt wouldn't be a major tournament for Southgate's England without a goal from Kane.\n\nAfter failing to really get involved in the opening game against Serbia, Kane was right in the thick of things here as he netted from close range in the first half.\n\nAfter good work from Kyle Walker on the right, he cut the ball back to Bukayo Saka, but the ball eventually found it's way to Kane who had an easy tap in.\n\nThat was tournament goal number 13 for Kane and his 63rd for the national team.\n\nAfter the England goal, Southgate's side, once again, seemed to drop off and go into their shell which allowed their opponents to grow in confidence.\n\nAfter a dispossession in the middle of the park, Sporting Lisbon midfielder Hjulmand took a couple of touches before firing into the corner.\n\nEverton goalkeeper Jordan Pickford had no chance with the effort which was the first goal that the Three Lions have conceded in the group stage of a major tournament since Gareth Bale's freekick in 2016.\n\nManchester City midfielder Phil Foden won the Premier League Player Of The Year award and looked set to be in for a key tournament in Germany.\n\nHowever, so far after two group games for England, Foden has looked invisible off the left and Southgate has to make a decision on the City midfielder.\n\nFoden's qualities are clear but the Englishman cannot continue to play off the left as this seems to stifle the Three Lions.\n\nThere has been much debate about Trent Alexander-Arnold's position in the team with Southgate choosing to play the Liverpool defender in the middle of the park.\n\nAfter a poor showing against Serbia, the Liverpool man was kept in the same role for the game {"uri": "8184918504", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "08:19:41", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T08:19:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T08:18:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13546009/5-memorable-matches-England-Denmark-ahead-Euro-2024-clash.html", "title": "5 memorable matches between England and Denmark ahead of their Euro...", "body": "England face Denmark on Thursday in their second Group C game at Euro 2024.\n\nHere, the PA news agency looks at some of the most memorable contests between the two sides.\n\nEngland 5 Denmark 2 (World Cup qualifier, December 1956)\n\nTommy Taylor starred for England (PA)\n\nTommy Taylor set the ball rolling in just the second minute of what proved a high-scoring game, before netting his second in the 22nd minute.\n\nOve Bech Nielsen got the Danes back into the game with a goal in the 27th minute but Taylor completed his hat-trick early in the second half to give England more breathing space.\n\nNielsen replied by scoring his second goal of the game before Duncan Edwards restored England's two-goal advantage almost instantly and then scored again to take the game out of Denmark's reach.\n\nDenmark 3 England 4 (Euro 1980 qualifier, September 1978)\n\nEngland and Denmark delivered a seven-goal thriller in the Euro 1980 qualifying campaign. Kevin Keegan scored twice inside 21 minutes but Denmark were soon level courtesy of an Allan Simonsen penalty and a goal from Frank Arnesen.\n\nEngland regained their two-goal lead in the second half thanks to Bob Latchford and Phil Neal but just 13 seconds after England's fourth goal, Per Rontved got one back for Denmark. Despite this, England managed to hold on for the victory.\n\nDenmark 0 England 3 (World Cup 2002 round of 16, June 2002)\n\nRio Ferdinand celebrates after England beat Denmark (Rui Vieira/PA)\n\nEngland reached the quarter-finals of World Cup 2002 after ultimately beating Denmark in the first half with three goals without reply.\n\nRio Ferdinand got England up and running after netting inside the first five minutes, then a 22-year-old Michael Owen doubled the lead in the 22nd minute.\n\nJust before half-time, Emile Heskey joined the party with a goal to give Sven-Goran Eriksson's side a healthy lead going into the second half, which produced no further goals.\n\nDenmark 4 England 1 (friendly, August 2005)\n\nA friendly in the summer of 2005 saw Denmark comfortably beat England in Copenhagen. Denmark scored three goals in eight second-half minutes through Dennis Rommedahl, Jon Dahl Tomasson and Michael Gravgaard.\n\nEngland managed to get one back in the 87th minute thanks to Wayne Rooney, however this was merely a consolation as in the second minute of added time Soren Larsen scored Denmark's fourth.\n\nEngland 2 Denmark 1 (Euro 2020 semi-final, July 2021)\n\nGareth Southgate's side kept their Euro 2020 hopes alive by making their way into the final after overcoming a resilient Denmark side.\n\nIt was not simple for England as in the 30th minute Mikkel Damsgaard stuck a powerful free-kick into the top-left corner, leaving a flailing Jordan Pickford with no chance and putting the Danes 1-0 up.\n\nSoon after, England were back level after an own goal from a low Bukayo Saka These are two teams with points on the board in Group C but with room for improvement. They also know each other pretty well.\n\nThis Euro 2024 match kicks off from the Waldstadion at 6 p.m. local time Thursday, June 20, in Frankfurt, Germany.\n\nHere's how that time translates across some of the major territories around the globe:\n\nLuke Shaw continued to train away from his team-mates as he builds match fitness, so the game in Frankfurt comes too soon for the Manchester United left-back to start.\n\nGareth Southgate could stick with an unchanged XI from the Serbia game, giving the Trent Alexander-Arnold midfield experiment another chance to bed in. Conor Gallagher and Kobbie Mainoo appeared as substitutes at the weekend and are the most likely alternatives to the Liverpool star.\n\nEngland projected starting lineup (4-2-3-1): Pickford (GK) -- Walker, Stones, Guehi, Trippier -- Alexander-Arnold, Rice -- Saka, Bellingham, Foden -- Kane.\n\nKasper Hjulmand could similarly field an unchanged side, although Joakim Maehle could provide an attacking outlet at wing-back.\n\nManchester United striker Rasmus Hojlund has seven goals in 15 international caps and will lead the line for his country once more.\n\nDenmark projected starting lineup (3-4-1-2): Schmeichel (GK) -- Andersen, Christensen, Vestergaard -- Bah, Hjulmand, Hojbjerg, Kristiansen -- Eriksen -- Wind, Hojlund.\n\nHere's how to watch this Euro 2024 match across selected areas of the world's major regions:\n\nUSA: England vs. Denmark from the Waldstadion will be televised in the United States on FOX, with a Spanish-language broadcast via Vix. Both channels are available to stream on Fubo with the latter offering a FREE seven-day trial. Sling will also be live-streaming the match.\n\nRadio coverage of the match can be followed on SiriusXM FC.\n\nUK: Thursday's match will be shown in the UK on BBC One and the free-to-air broadcaster's Player and website platforms.\n\nCanada: Euro 2024 matches can be seen in Canada on TSN's respective TV channel and live streaming services.\n\nAustralia: Australia's sole broadcaster for England vs. Denmark is Optus Sport.\n\nIndia: Euro 2024 matches are available to watch on JioTV and Sony LIV.
