With a total of 24 touches by the end of the game, the ex-Tottenham Hotspur striker opted not to drop deep in search of possession.\n\nJude Bellingham and Bukayo Saka played vital attacking roles for the Three Lions, but Kane's minimal involvement could be an early sign that Southgate needs to alter his tactics. As England prepare to face Denmark on Thursday (5pm), Manchester United legend Wes Brown has urged his ex-England teammate Southgate to allow Kane to take centre stage.\n\nSpeaking on Reach's new Euro Thrash podcast - which you can find on YouTube, Apple and Spotify - Brown said: \"He's the main guy, but he needs more of the ball, more service. Because Jude [Bellingham] is right behind him, likes to get on the ball wherever, so that doesn't help Harry Kane with his touches and his lead-up play.\n\nREAD MORE: 'Bang in trouble' - Rio Ferdinand issues radical Bukayo Saka demand for England\n\nREAD MORE: BBC releases statement after Gary Lineker appears to break rules during Euro 2024 coverage\n\n\"It would be good if he could get more touches, bring more people into play and ultimately Harry [Kane] is there in the end as a six-yard man, getting into that space. That is where you want him.\n\n\"He is not the one who is going to turn defenders and sprint onto the ball, that is not his game. He's getting the ball when we are moving up slowly and when we do get an opportunity, he will be in the right space.\"\n\nDespite Kane being occupied with keeping Serbia's back three busy and creating room for England's creative midfielders, only a stunning save from Predrag Rajkovic stopped him from adding his name to the scoresheet with a second-half header. Brown recognises Kane's strength as a lone striker but believes a minor adjustment could unleash England's all-time top scorer.\n\n\"You want him in the box. We need someone there to occupy the last two defenders so we can create some space around and I do think he does that well,\" Brown added.\n\n\"Kane will be looking at it when we've got the ball in possession, he'll know these lads are capable of creating and making things happen, and if one of the opposition messes up, I'll be in that little bit of space to get a shot off and try and score.\"\n\n\"He will be looking and thinking 'I want to be in that game, I want to be the guy, I want to be the star who scores', but teams do make it difficult for you these days.\"\n\nEngland have the chance to secure their spot in the knockout stages with a victory over Denmark, who started their campaign with a draw against Slovenia. supporters as teams draw at Euro 2024 match", "body": "In an event which has been more entertaining than basically everything which occurred during England's 1-1 draw with Denmark at Euro 2024, the Danish fans decided to deploy a rather NSFW chant ahead of the game.\n\nIf you've just been watching the Three Lions put on a display about as scintillating as a dentist appointment then you might appreciate some levity.\n\nEngland went ahead first thanks to an early Harry Kane goal, but almost immediately sat deep and invited pressure.\n\nA misplaced pass from Kane set up Morten Hjulmand to put the ball past Pickford from distance, and from there things were distinctly unexciting as England didn't craft many more exciting chances.\n\nPhil Foden and Jude Bellingham both appeared to be trying to play in the same spot, Trent Alexander-Arnold in midfield doesn't seem to be working and beyond the goals the most exciting moment was when Gareth Southgate decided to switch out his entire forward line.\n\nYep, that's the level of entertainment we got that we're discussing a triple substitution being a moment of excitement.\n\nAnyhow, only what the Danish fans were up to that was so noteworthy.\n\nBefore the game, back in that realm when anything was possible and England vs Denmark might have been a scintillating spectacle instead of the match we actually got, Danish fans had their chants ready.\n\nThey were inviting English supporters to 'stick your f**king teabag up your a**e', and frankly if you spent the past 90 minutes doing that then you probably had a better time than if you'd watched the game.\n\nStill, some England fans said the teabag chant was 'bang out of order', while others said it was 'too far' from the Danes.\n\nSuch clap-backs from England fans might have held weight before the game, but after the Three Lions served up a level of fun you'd expect from a seminar at a data entry company there's really not a lot of ammunition to strike back.\n\nFor some reason England were named the bookies favourites to win Euro 2024, but with performances like that it's definitely not happening and they'll be rolled over the first time they end up on a pitch with one of the other big boys of Europe.\n\nSorry to be so negative, dear reader, but I just sat through 90 minutes of relative drudgery where England seem to be making the mistakes we so often make at international tournaments and I'm not having a fun time.\n\nI'm also reminded of that second half performance during England's 1-0 win over Serbia in their first game of the tournament, where I basically lost the will to live.\n\nHere's hoping that England have something better to offer against Slovenia in the third group game next Tuesday (25 June) and we prove that the received wisdom of the eventual tournament winner starting slowly is true.\n\nIt might not feel like it right now but maybe it's still coming home.\n\nAs for storing your teabags, do not follow the advice on Danish fans {"uri": "8185287255", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "12:17:42", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T12:17:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T12:16:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/football/article/2024/jun/19/unselfish-harry-kane-can-shift-roles-it-doesnt-often-affect-his-england-goals", "title": "Unselfish Harry Kane can shift roles, it doesn't often affect his England goals", "body": "Captain can drop deep or play as a classic No 9 and will mix it up depending on the opponent and the state of the game\n\nWembley Stadium, 7 July 2021, a crisis brewing. Denmark are 1-0 up against England in the Euro 2020 semi-final, Mikel Damsgaard's free-kick catching Jordan Pickford out, and the hosts are beginning to panic.\n\nAnd so Harry Kane drops deep. All tournament long, people have questioned why he drops deep. Why isn't England's No 9 in the box? Why is he so far from goal? Is it ego that makes him think he's a No 10? Well, here's the answer. Receiving the ball midway inside Denmark's half, Kane controls with his left foot and then, with no backlift, plays a defence-splitting pass with his right. Away goes Bukayo Saka, streaking clear on the right, and when the winger's low cross ends up being turned into his own goal by Simon Kjaer, England are back on the victory path.\n\nKane's ingenuity is the turning point. He had been adjusting after his ankle injuries, running the channels less and operating more as a playmaker, while still retaining that enormous goal threat. He is neither a No 9 nor a No 10; instead he is a 9.5, a mix of Alan Shearer and Teddy Sheringham, the dip in the power of his running no impediment to him pulling away from centre-backs, turning and sending a wide forward away with a sweeping pass.\n\nWe saw it so often when he linked up with Son Heung-min at Tottenham. He moved to Bayern Munich last summer and finished his first season in Germany with 44 goals and eight assists in all competitions. And last Sunday, as England opened their Euro 2024 campaign with a 1-0 win over Serbia, he managed two touches in the first half, spent most of the game being buffeted by three big defenders and did not have an attempt on goal until late in the game.\n\nIt was an Erling Haaland-esque performance: low involvement in the buildup, plenty of frustration, a narrative defined by whether or not the big chance ends up in the back of the net. Afterwards, though, Kane and Southgate were satisfied with how things had gone. Kane explained that it was part of the plan for him to play high and make space for Jude Bellingham and Phil Foden in between the lines. Southgate talked about the captain's hold-up play relieving pressure in the second half. Jamie Carragher, writing in his Daily Telegraph column, said England will not win the Euros if Kane is unable to resume his old playmaking role. Why is he playing so high? Why is he in the box all the time?\n\nYet, as Kane said, each game will be different. He was doubted at the start of Euro 2020 and the 2022 World Cup, only to respond with a flurry of goals on both occasions. Do not bet against Kane. There will be goals and assists. They could come when England face Denmark again in Frankfurt on Thursday.\n\nAn altered role does not have to spell disaster for Kane. Equally, though, it is clear that the nature of England's attack has shifted since the early Southgate era. One of the team's biggest wins, the 3-2 triumph over Spain in October 2018, was built on Kane dropping back and releasing Marcus Rashford and Raheem Sterling with clever through balls. England had pace and directness in the wide areas, with Sterling particularly influential on the left at the last Euros. Against Serbia, though, the speed was limited to Saka on the right. Phil Foden, a more technical player than Sterling, would spend his time drifting in from the opposite flank. Behind Kane, meanwhile, was a 20-year-old superstar who oozes main character energy.\n\nInevitably there will be questions about whether the irrepressible rise of Jude Bellingham will steal Kane's thunder. Who is England's talisman now? Maybe it's the wrong question to ask. Maybe, as Southgate says, England do not need a talisman. It will help Kane if some of the pressure is lifted from his shoulders.\n\nThe captain is, first and foremost, an incredible team player. Kane is obsessed with scoring but if he has to sacrifice himself for the team he will do it. He didn't actually have a bad game against Serbia; he wasn't losing balls in the first half, he just wasn't getting anything to feet. Everything centred around Bellingham's energy. Kane occupied defenders. There was space for Bellingham to make a late run into the box. In the second half Kane held the ball up, won free-kicks and hit the bar with his one chance. The narrative would have been different if that had gone in.\n\nEven then, though, the comparison with Haaland would not quite be right. Haaland is rarely involved in City's buildup play. The Norwegian's game is almost entirely defined by whether he scores but Kane is different. He can do almost everything. He was perfectly capable of fighting Serbia's bruisers in the air.\n\nPerhaps it can be put to one side. After all, when England beat Italy last October, the move that led to their equalising penalty came from Kane dropping back, holding off his marker and laying the ball off for Bellingham to surge through on goal. Everything seemed to be in fine working order then and the lesson is that Kane is going to make his presence felt at some point. It might be a towering header at the back post, a fizzing shot or one of those trademark assists. One way or another, it's coming.", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jacob_steinberg@theguardian.com", "name": "Jacob Steinberg", a team with as much playmaking talent as anybody in this tournament.\n\nDenmark will be feeling plenty of pressure after a 1-1 draw with Slovenia.\n\nThe Danes started well and could have put the game away with a second goal in the first half, but they allowed Slovenia to hang around and paid the price.\n\nDenmark was a tad fortunate not to lose given how the final 30 minutes played out.\n\nYou'd No chance with the goal.\n\nKyle Walker 6\n\nAgeless. Great opportunism and athleticism to make England's opener.\n\nJohn Stones 5\n\nNeeded to use his experience to urge England's midfield higher up the pitch. Some good defending deep in his own box but not as composed as usual.\n\nMarc Guehi 6\n\nGood, aggressive stuff from the Crystal Palace man. Showed Serbia performance was no fluke. Vital recovery from his own error late on.\n\nKieran Trippier 5\n\nWon his 50th cap and was his usual reliable self defensively but England continue to be lop-sided in attack\n\nTrent Alexander-Arnold 4\n\nA tough evening. Loose in possession and his lack of experience in midfield told with some dreadful positioning off the ball. Far too deep. Time up on the experiment?\n\nDeclan Rice 5\n\nLike Alexander-Arnold, played on top of his centre-backs when England needed someone to step out. Still effective in breaking up the play but far from flawless with the ball.\n\nBukayo Saka 6\n\nSo important to this team. Takes the ball under pressure and drives England up the pitch. Again gave his full-back a torrid time.\n\nJude Bellingham 5\n\nHuge contrast with the first-half against Serbia. Unable to get in the game in the opening 45 minutes here from No10. More involved in the second-half, creating Watkins chance, but guilty of overplaying.\n\nPhil Foden 6\n\nA big improvement after a quiet start. Went close with a couple of curlers, hit the post, showed his class with some nice runs. The Newcastle man did not do too much wrong, but has to look inside too much. 6/10\n\nDeclan Rice\n\nPlayed too deep in front of the back four and could not get a grip of the game as he does for Arsenal. {"uri": "8187550688", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:36:39", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:36:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:35:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/sport/football/news/england-denmark-euro-2024-kane-33074952", "title": "Harry Kane call was no-brainer - but he's not only England star underperforming", "body": "Harry Kane was subbed off by Gareth Southgate during England's draw with Denmark\n\nAs you would expect, Harry Kane took it well, unfastening his armband and jogging smartly towards Kyle Walker to hand it over.\n\nBut it must have hurt. Being hooked with a good 20 minutes left probably always hurts. Being hooked when you are the England captain and record scorer - at a stage when your team is hunting a goal - has to be particularly painful.\n\nAnd what must have hurt Kane most of all is that it was the right call. In fact, by that point, it was a no-brainer.\n\nIt was an obvious shout even though he had scored the 64th goal of his England career and his 13th in tournament football - a goal that eventually meant Gareth Southgate's team took away a point their performance did not deserve.\n\nBut of all the worrying, error-ridden, below-par individual displays in this desperately disappointing England showing, Kane's was one of the most eye-catching. And not just because his uncharacteristically loose pass gave Denmark the possession which led to Morten Hjulmand's splendidly-struck equaliser.\n\nAfter being gifted the effort that now means he has scored in four successive major tournaments, Kane looked off the pace throughout, laboured and ineffective. In the win over Serbia in last Sunday's Group C opener, Kane had 24 touches. In this grim draw against the Danes, Kane had 22 touches.\n\nDropping deep into territory in which Jude Bellingham was already wandering aimlessly, Kane barely posed a threat after capitalising on Kyle Walker's good work and a couple of diversions off Danish defenders for his routine finish.\n\nAnd against robust opposition, Kane seemed to find it something of a physical struggle. Kane was struggling with a back injury ahead of Bayern Munich's Champions League semi-final second leg in Madrid and, on reflection, Thomas Tuchel thought it might have been a mistake to play him in that match.\n\nKane then missed Bayern's final game of the Bundesliga season but was keen to dispel any fears he might be struggling when he joined up with England. That continues to be the party line but contributions such as this one make you wonder if he really is anywhere near 100 per cent sharp.\n\nNot that many England players looked sharp in this disjointed, painful, laborious slog towards a point that leaves them top of their qualifying table. Bar a decent late pass for substitute Ollie Watkins, Bellingham had such a poor game that it was actually unfathomable. It was hard to find a reason for it.\n\nThere was nothing Ballon D'Or about it, that is for sure and it was something of a surprise that he stayed on the field when Southgate made the raft of changes that included the skipper's removal.\n\nBellingham's pass for Watkins gave the Aston Villa striker a sneaky chance of a late winner but Kasper Schmeichel saved. Still, Watkins was lively enough in the quarter of a game he was given to at least suggest he IS a viable alternative to Kane.\n\nNot that Southgate would ever think about relegating a fit Kane to the bench. The fact remains that he is England's main scoring hope and this team's leader.\n\nHe was out there at the end, leading the applause for the disgruntled fans and shaking the hand of every squad-mate. But there is no escaping one fact. Right now, England have too many underperforming blue-chip players.\n\nAnd Harry Kane is most definitely one of them.\n\nJoin our new WhatsApp communityand receive your daily dose of Mirror Football content. {"uri": "8187657964", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "20:16:53", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T20:16:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T20:15:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://www.indy100.com/sport/english-fan-and-danish-wife-still-alive-after-1-1-draw-at-euros", "title": "English fan and Danish wife 'still alive' after 1-1 draw at Euros", "body": "England supporter Michael Wild and his Danish wife, Joan, watched England face Denmark in Euro 2024 (Michael Wild/PA)\n\nAn England football fan, who watched his team face Denmark at the Euros with his Danish wife, said the atmosphere at home was \"interesting\" but joked they are \"still alive\" and have not \"fallen out\".\n\nMichael Wild, 74, from Colesbourne, Gloucestershire, and wife Joan watched England draw 1-1 with Denmark in Frankfurt, Germany, missing the chance to top their European Championship group with a game to spare.\n\nThe England supporter and his Denmark-supporting wife sat in their front room together to watch the game, each displaying opposing reactions but joked they remain on good terms.\n\nMr Wild told the PA news agency: \"We're all fine. We're still alive and nobody's fallen out.\n\n\"We watched it at home sitting next to each other in adjacent chairs making our own comments as we went along.\n\n\"It was interesting listening to comments of 'that was good' or 'that was awful' coming out at the same time.\"\n\nAsked about his thoughts moments after the match, he added: \"My reaction was 'oh dear' and the wife's reaction was 'oh great' and I've been getting messages (from family) of 'you were rubbish'.\n\nThe football fan predicted watching England face Denmark would be \"a bit of fun\" but admits his wife is \"a lot happier than I am\". Both agreed \"Denmark probably deserved to win it and England was pretty poor\".\n\nMrs Wild waved the Danish flag post-match while Mr Wild looked \"particularly glum\" on his living room chair but said a trip to his local pub helped his mood.\n\n\"Best thing to do is come and relax over a quiet pint and a cigar at the garden of my local pub,\" he said.\n\nMr Wild said the 1-1 outcome was not as he expected but agreed to offer his support for both England and Denmark throughout the tournament.\n\n\"It was not what I'd expected or it's not what I'd hoped for, but now I can go through the rest of the tournament quite happily supporting Denmark when they play and England when they play and hopefully they won't meet each other again,\" the England supporter said.\n\nBefore the match, Mr Wild predicted England would win 2-1 but described their performance on Thursday as \"appalling\".\n\n\"I thought it was a pretty appalling performance but it's no different than what we've seen over the last few games,\" he said.\n\n\"Harry Kane's goal was Harry Kane doing what Harry Kane does best. In a 90-minute game, if you only give him one opportunity don't expect miracles.\n\n\"I thought his goal was great, somewhat fortuitous, but well taken.\"\n\nHe also feels England manager Gareth Southgate could do more to \"move England forward\".\n\n\"Not that I know anything at all about football tactics but I don't think Southgate has got the balance at all right. The midfield seems to be a non-entity,\" he said.\n\n\"My own personal view is he's been in the role for eight years and he hasn't moved England forward.\"\n\nAt the end of the day, it's a sport and it's a bit of fun - don't let it affect your relationship\n\nMr Wild described the group-stage game as somewhat poignant as it came 40 years after the Danes beat England in a Euro 1984 qualifying match at Wembley.\n\nMr and Mrs Wild recalled being on their honeymoon in France during the football tournament.\n\nNow, 40 years on, the couple watched as England drew 1-1 against Denmark in a result Mr Wild did not expect.\n\nHe joked: \"At the end of the day, it's a sport and it's a bit of fun. Don't let it affect your relationship.\"", "source": {"uri": "indy100.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "indy100.com"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8187636818", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "20:02:28", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T20:02:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:55:40Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/english-fan-danish-wife-still-195215915.html", "title": "English fan and Danish wife 'still alive' after 1-1 draw at Euros", "body": "An England football fan, who watched his team face Denmark at the Euros with his Danish wife, said the atmosphere at home was \"interesting\" but joked they are \"still alive\" and have not \"fallen out\".\n\nMichael Wild, 74, from Colesbourne, Gloucestershire, and wife Joan watched England draw 1-1 with Denmark in Frankfurt, Germany, missing the chance to top their European Championship group with a game to spare.\n\nThe England supporter and his Denmark-supporting wife sat in their front room together to watch the game, each displaying opposing reactions but joked they remain on good terms.\n\nMr Wild told the PA news agency: \"We're all fine. We're still alive and nobody's fallen out.\n\n\"We watched it at home sitting next to each other in adjacent chairs making our own comments as we went along.\n\n\"It was interesting listening to comments of 'that was good' or 'that was awful' coming out at the same time.\"\n\nAsked about his thoughts moments after the match, he added: \"My reaction was 'oh dear' and the wife's reaction was 'oh great' and I've been getting messages (from family) of 'you were rubbish'.\n\nThe football fan predicted watching England face Denmark would be \"a bit of fun\" but admits his wife is \"a lot happier than I am\". Both agreed \"Denmark probably deserved to win it and England was pretty poor\".\n\nMrs Wild waved the Danish flag post-match while Mr Wild looked \"particularly glum\" on his living room chair but said a trip to his local pub helped his mood.\n\n\"Best thing to do is come and relax over a quiet pint and a cigar at the garden of my local pub,\" he said.\n\nMr Wild said the 1-1 outcome was not as he expected but agreed to offer his support for both England and Denmark throughout the tournament.\n\n\"It was not what I'd expected or it's not what I'd hoped for, but now I can go through the rest of the tournament quite happily supporting Denmark when they play and England when they play and hopefully they won't meet each other again,\" the England supporter said.\n\nBefore the match, Mr Wild predicted England would win 2-1 but described their performance on Thursday as \"appalling\".\n\n\"I thought it was a pretty appalling performance but it's no different than what we've seen over the last few games,\" he said.\n\n\"Harry Kane's goal was Harry Kane doing what Harry Kane does best. In a 90-minute game, if you only give him one opportunity don't expect miracles.\n\n\"I thought his goal was great, somewhat fortuitous, but well taken.\"\n\nHe also feels England manager Gareth Southgate could do more to \"move England forward\".\n\n\"Not that I know anything at all about football tactics but I don't think Southgate has got the balance at all right. The midfield seems to be a non-entity,\" he said.\n\n\"My own personal view is he's been in the role for eight years and he hasn't moved England forward.\"\n\nMr Wild described the group-stage game as somewhat poignant as it came 40 years after the Danes beat England in a Euro 1984 qualifying match at Wembley.\n\nMr and Mrs Wild recalled being on their honeymoon in France during the football tournament.\n\nNow, 40 years on, the couple watched as England drew 1-1 against Denmark in a result Mr Wild did not expect.\n\nHe joked: \"At the end of the day, it's a sport and it's a bit of fun. Don't let it affect your relationship.\"", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/England", {"uri": "8187659412", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "20:18:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T20:18:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T20:17:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/pa/article-13552555/English-fan-Danish-wife-alive-1-1-draw-Euros.html", "title": "English fan and Danish wife 'still alive\u00b4 after 1-1 draw at Euros", "body": "An England football fan, who watched his team face Denmark at the Euros with his Danish wife, said the atmosphere at home was \"interesting\" but joked they are \"still alive\" and have not \"fallen out\".\n\nMichael Wild, 74, from Colesbourne, Gloucestershire, and wife Joan watched England draw 1-1 with Denmark in Frankfurt, Germany, missing the chance to top their European Championship group with a game to spare.\n\nThe England supporter and his Denmark-supporting wife sat in their front room together to watch the game, each displaying opposing reactions but joked they remain on good terms.\n\nMr Wild told the PA news agency: \"We're all fine. We're still alive and nobody's fallen out.\n\nDenmark supporter Joan Wild smiling and waving the Danish flag following England\u00b4s 1-1 draw against Denmark (Michael Wild)\n\n\"We watched it at home sitting next to each other in adjacent chairs making our own comments as we went along.\n\n\"It was interesting listening to comments of 'that was good' or 'that was awful' coming out at the same time.\"\n\nAsked about his thoughts moments after the match, he added: \"My reaction was 'oh dear' and the wife's reaction was 'oh great' and I've been getting messages (from family) of 'you were rubbish'.\n\nThe football fan predicted watching England face Denmark would be \"a bit of fun\" but admits his wife is \"a lot happier than I am\". Both agreed \"Denmark probably deserved to win it and England was pretty poor\".\n\nMrs Wild waved the Danish flag post-match while Mr Wild looked \"particularly glum\" on his living room chair but said a trip to his local pub helped his mood.\n\n\"Best thing to do is come and relax over a quiet pint and a cigar at the garden of my local pub,\" he said.\n\nMr Wild said the 1-1 outcome was not as he expected but agreed to offer his support for both England and Denmark throughout the tournament.\n\n\"It was not what I'd expected or it's not what I'd hoped for, but now I can go through the rest of the tournament quite happily supporting Denmark when they play and England when they play and hopefully they won't meet each other again,\" the England supporter said.\n\nEngland supporter Michael Wild looking glum after England\u00b4s 1-1 draw against Denmark (Michael Wild)\n\nBefore the match, Mr Wild predicted England would win 2-1 but described their performance on Thursday as \"appalling\".\n\n\"I thought it was a pretty appalling performance but it's no different than what we've seen over the last few games,\" he said.\n\n\"Harry Kane's goal was Harry Kane doing what Harry Kane does best. In a 90-minute game, if you only give him one opportunity don't expect miracles.\n\n\"I thought his goal was great, somewhat fortuitous, but well taken.\"\n\nHe also feels England manager Gareth Southgate could do more to \"move England forward\".\n\n\"Not that I know anything at all about football tactics but I don't think Southgate has got the balance at all right. The midfield seems to be a non-entity,\" he said.\n\n\"My own personal view is he's been in the role for eight years and he hasn't moved England forward.\"\n\nAt the end of the day, it's a sport and it's a bit of fun - don't let it affect your relationship Michael Wild, England supporter\n\nMr Wild described the group-stage game as somewhat poignant as it came 40 years after the Danes beat England in a Euro 1984 qualifying match at Wembley.\n\nMr and Mrs Wild recalled being on their honeymoon in France during the football tournament.\n\nNow, 40 years on, the couple watched as England drew 1-1 against Denmark in a result Mr Wild did not expect.\n\nHe joked: \"At the end of the day, it's a sport and it's a bit of fun. {"uri": "8187643365", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "20:03:01", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T20:03:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T20:01:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://guernseypress.com/news/uk-news/2024/06/20/english-fan-and-danish-wife-still-alive-after-1-1-draw-at-euros/", "title": "English fan and Danish wife 'still alive' after 1-1 draw at Euros", "body": "England supporter Michael Wild and his Denmark-supporting wife Joan sat in their front room together to watch the game.\n\nAn England football fan, who watched his team face Denmark at the Euros with his Danish wife, said the atmosphere at home was \"interesting\" but joked they are \"still alive\" and have not \"fallen out\".\n\nMichael Wild, 74, from Colesbourne, Gloucestershire, and wife Joan watched England draw 1-1 with Denmark in Frankfurt, Germany, missing the chance to top their European Championship group with a game to spare.\n\nThe England supporter and his Denmark-supporting wife sat in their front room together to watch the game, each displaying opposing reactions but joked they remain on good terms.\n\nMr Wild told the PA news agency: \"We're all fine. We're still alive and nobody's fallen out.\n\n\"It was interesting listening to comments of 'that was good' or 'that was awful' coming out at the same time.\"\n\nAsked about his thoughts moments after the match, he added: \"My reaction was 'oh dear' and the wife's reaction was 'oh great' and I've been getting messages (from family) of 'you were rubbish'.\n\nThe football fan predicted watching England face Denmark would be \"a bit of fun\" but admits his wife is \"a lot happier than I am\". Both agreed \"Denmark probably deserved to win it and England was pretty poor\".\n\nMrs Wild waved the Danish flag post-match while Mr Wild looked \"particularly glum\" on his living room chair but said a trip to his local pub helped his mood.\n\n\"Best thing to do is come and relax over a quiet pint and a cigar at the garden of my local pub,\" he said.\n\nMr Wild said the 1-1 outcome was not as he expected but agreed to offer his support for both England and Denmark throughout the tournament.\n\n\"It was not what I'd expected or it's not what I'd hoped for, but now I can go through the rest of the tournament quite happily supporting Denmark when they play and England when they play and hopefully they won't meet each other again,\" the England supporter said.\n\n\"I thought it was a pretty appalling performance but it's no different than what we've seen over the last few games,\" he said.\n\n\"Harry Kane's goal was Harry Kane doing what Harry Kane does best. In a 90-minute game, if you only give him one opportunity don't expect miracles.\n\n\"I thought his goal was great, somewhat fortuitous, but well taken.\"\n\nHe also feels England manager Gareth Southgate could do more to \"move England forward\".\n\n\"Not that I know anything at all about football tactics but I don't think Southgate has got the balance at all right. The midfield seems to be a non-entity,\" he said.\n\n\"My own personal view is he's been in the role for eight years and he hasn't moved England forward.\"\n\nMr and Mrs Wild recalled being on their honeymoon in France during the football tournament.\n\nNow, 40 years on, the couple watched as England drew 1-1 against Denmark in a result Mr Wild did not expect.\n\nHe joked: \"At the end of the day, it's a sport and it's a bit of fun. {"uri": "8185635531", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "16:17:08", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T16:17:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T16:16:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4980392158031464, "url": "https://www.sportingnews.com/us/soccer/news/england-vs-denmark-prediction-odds-betting-euro-2024-group/5fc4cbb470d928f5dc94c8fa", "title": "England vs. Denmark prediction, odds, betting tips and best bets for Euro 2024 favorites in group stage", "body": "After securing a valuable three points in their opener amidst a sputtering performance, Euro 2024 favorites England now look to lock down a place in the knockout stage as they meet Denmark in Group C play.\n\nThe Three Lions were poor on the whole but managed to see out a 1-0 victory over Serbia in their first match of the tournament. Still, the result coupled with poor performances in the pre-tournament friendlies, have some England fans worried about their viability as Euro title contenders.\n\nEngland have a wealth of attacking talent, but it was Jude Bellingham's 12th-minute goal that did the business, as the likes of Phil Foden and Harry Kane fell flat. The positives came from the back line as defender Marc Guehi impressed while helping hold Serbia to just a single shot on target.\n\nDenmark opened with a disappointing 1-1 draw against Slovenia, as Christian Eriksen's emotional early opener was eventually canceled out in the 77th minute. It leaves them desperate for points amid remaining matches against the competition favorites and then a physical and talented Serbia.\n\nEngland were far from convincing in their Euro 2024 opener, and there are plenty of reasons to be concerned about their ability to beat others in this tournament field, but this is not the spot where they will falter.\n\nDenmark were also unconvincing in their first game and have been less than impressive in recent months overall. Their recent wins over Sweden and Faroe Islands were far closer than the disparity in talent between the sides should indicate, and they've also been on the wrong end of disappointing results against Switzerland and Northern Ireland.\n\nThe Three Lions have attacking issues to sort out, but so do their opponents, and talent will win out in this game.\n\nEngland boss Gareth Southgate has a similar mentality to that of France head coach Didier Deschamps. They both have a wealth of world-class attacking talent in the squad, yet each coach understands that in competitive international football, the tactics must be simple and the results come any way possible, even if they're far from enjoyable to watch.\n\nSouthgate is happy to sit on a lead, just as England did against Serbia, smothering the opponent who never presented a true threat to the one-goal advantage.\n\nThey'll approach this match in a similar manner. The defensive partnership of John Stones and Marc Guehi was impressive in the opener, while Kieran Trippier and Kyle Walker are defensively adept alongside their abilities to go forward. Declan Rice is one of the best in the world at the six, and even No. 10 Jude Bellingham provides exceptional defensive contributions.\n\nDenmark will have no way through after an overall poor attacking performance in their opener, where Christian Eriksen's lone goal provided a third of their total 1.66 expected goal haul and almost half their 1.97 xGOT.\n\nFew players in this summer's tournament field are owed a European Championship goal like Bukayo Saka, who has yet to score in a Euro match across his five career appearances.\n\nThe 22-year-old has a high work rate and is asked to do a lot of dirty work in the England setup, and somehow has never even taken a single shot in any of his five Euro games. Yet he always presents a danger in the attacking third, having scored three goals at the 2022 World Cup and four more in the latest round of Euro qualifying, and his creative juices are always flowing as well.\n\nSaka's assist on Jude Bellingham's goal in England's opener is his second in a Euro match following one against this very opponent, Denmark, in the Euro 2020 semifinal. "sim": 0.4941176474094391, "url": "https://talksport.com/football/1929968/england-player-ratings-declan-rice-gareth-southgate-denmark/", "title": "Rice gets 2/10 as Southgate told to make 'drastic changes' after woeful draw", "body": "More questions were asked over Gareth Southgate's tactics and team selection as England laboured to a 1-1 draw with Denmark in their second Euro 2024 game.\n\nThe Three Lions had the chance to win Group C and book their place in the knockout phase with two games to spare, but instead they were booed off the pitch by fans in the stadium and no doubt from those sitting at home, too.\n\nOn paper, England have one of the strongest teams in international football, jam packed with forward-thinking players who light up the Premier League on a weekly basis.\n\nAnd yet against Denmark it appeared the creativity and flair we see from Trent Alexander-Arnold, Phil Foden, Bukayo Saka and Jude Bellingham was sapped out of them.\n\nHarry Kane's opener in the 18th minute looked to have set England on their way to a big win over an ageing Denmark team, but fans frustrated with how they scored and then sat back in their opening win over Serbia were left absolutely fuming this time, as it happened again.\n\nPundits were angry too, with England legend Stuart Pearce saying on talkSPORT: \"We've got absolutely no idea what we're trying to achieve.\"\n\ntalkSPORT host Adrian Durham, reporting live from the Deutsche Bank Park in Frankfurt, delivered his marks out of ten after another unconvincing night for Southgate's men.\n\nTo the point as always, Durham wasted little time in getting stuck in on the England stars after a horrible game.\n\nHe said after the full-time whistle: \"England were clueless, talentless, hopeless, they lacked energy, they lacked ideas, they lacked quality. Just not good enough!\n\n\"It might be good enough to get out of the group, but I'm totally disappointed and deflated about what I've seen.\"\n\nWhile fans and pundits were raging about what they were seeing unfold on the pitch, it appeared some of the England stars were at odds with the tactics being given to them.\n\nThat's certainly something Adrian noticed from his position in the commentary gantry: \"At times it seemed like Declan Rice was arguing with Jordan Pickford.\n\n\"Pickford wanted to send the ball long, play a pass over the top of the Denmark defence for our front line to run onto, but Rice kept telling him to calm down and kept playing it short.\n\n\"There seemed to be debates between the two of them, especially in the second half, which was very frustrating.\n\n\"Rice was playing really deep, he sold Marc Guehi short with a pass backwards that nearly got us in trouble, and it was Guehi to the rescue. Rice was poor today, that's not normally him.\n\nRice was then handed a 2/10 rating by Durham, who said: \"He was so deep I thought he was in Switzerland, Rice kept telling everyone to slow down but God knows why. His worst performance for England.\"\n\nRice's midfield partner Alexander-Arnold didn't fare much better than the Arsenal star on Thursday.\n\nHe was substituted in the 53rd minute, which is the earliest change Southgate has ever made in a tournament game, for Conor Gallagher.\n\nOn giving Alexander-Arnold a 3/10, Durham said: \"The 'Trent in midfield' experiment isn't working.\"\n\nPerhaps more surprisingly it was an off-day for England's arguably two most important players in Kane and Bellingham, who were both given scores of 4/10.\n\nOn Bellingham, Durham said: \"A rare poor performance from the great man.\"\n\nAnd on Kane, Durham added: \"He scored but then gave the ball away carelessly for the Danes equaliser. Flat. Dragged off.\"\n\n\"Things have to change drastically,\" Adrian concluded.\n\n\"Again, the substitutions will be questioned. I was surprised Saka and Foden were taken off. I thought those two showed a lot of enterprise. There was a lot of energy from Saka, I thought he was one of our best players and yet they got taken off, it seemed very strange.\n\n\"And one more thing: Cole Palmer, arguably the best player in the Premier League towards the end of the season, sat on the bench and stayed there.\n\n\"What is going on with this England side? They were truly terrible here today and think they were lucky to get a draw.\n\n\"Boos from the England fans were warranted. In the context of this group it's not the end of the world,but if we're going to go deep in the tournament and we want to win the thing, we've got to play a whole lot better than that.\"", "source": Trent Alexander-Arnold struggled to impose himself on the game from central midfield - but it's another star in the team Jamie Carragher is concerned by.\n\n\"The problem with a player of Kane's many abilities is that it reduces his effectiveness by 50 per cent. Kane is a multi-tasking, modern centre forward who was reduced to one-dimension during the 1-0 win over Serbia,\" Carragher wrote in his column for The Telegraph.\n\n\"If Southgate persists with the same system for the rest of the tournament, their No 9 will be heavily compromised. Possibly too much. Having come into the Euros with a Phil Foden conundrum, after one game Southgate has a Kane one.\n\n\"In the first half, Kane registered just two touches of the ball. For a player of his class, that is deeply worrying.\"\n\nKane entered the Euros coming off the back of his most prolific season in front of goal at club level, having bagged 44 goals in 44 games. But, despite that goalscoring form, Carragher believes Kane should have the licence to get involved in the game more regularly, something he was renowned for doing at Tottenham.\n\nEngland next play Denmark at Euro 2024 on Thursday, with a win set to all-but guarantee the Three Lions' progression to the knockout stages. Kane will hope to find his form against the Danes, a side he scored against at the previous European Championship to help the side reach the final of the tournament at Wembley.\n\nWhile the stakes are slightly different this time around, Denmark could provide the England captain with the opportunity to kickstart his Euro 2024.\n\nGet a free live stream to watch Euro 2024 from anywhere in the world for the summer's big tournament. {"uri": "8187523683", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:14:59", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:14:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:13:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4941176474094391, "url": "https://ca.sports.yahoo.com/news/england-vs-denmark-player-ratings-180705427.html", "title": "England vs Denmark player ratings as Walker shines but Alexander-Arnold struggles again", "body": "Harry Kane opened his Euro 2024 account in the 18th minute before Denmark equalised through Morten Hjulmand's long-range strike as the Danes came back strong at the end of the first-half.\n\nDenmark had the better of the chances in the second-half as England wilted late on, but ultimately it was a point apiece in Frankfurt.\n\nEngland face Slovenia in their final Group C clash on Tuesday night, while Denmark take on Serbia.\n\nBut how did each player perform? Here are The Independent's player ratings:\n\nJordan Pickford - 6\n\nConceded his first goal of the tournament through Morten Hjulmand's long-range shot but can't really be blamed for a pinpoint strike. Otherwise assured and made the saves required.\n\nKyle Walker - 8\n\nEngland's best player on the day. Sat on his haunches early on as his foot gave way to the terrible turf underneath in Frankfurt, but that didn't defy him as he caught Victor Kristiansen off-guard and via a deflection found Harry Kane for the first goal. Continued to be a consistent source on the front-foot until the end.\n\nAnother largely assured performance from the Crystal Palace captain, until the end when he lost possession cheaply - but recovered well to deny Alexander Tah a shot at goal.\n\nKieran Trippier - 6\n\nA typically solid performance, though England miss a quick, surging outlet down the left-hand side in a similar vein to Walker on the right. But for what Trippier offers, he remains an adequate stand-in for Luke Shaw.\n\nDeclan Rice - 5\n\nA misplaced pass to Guehi which went out for a corner rather summed up the midfielder's afternoon. There's little alternative in his position, and covered plenty of ground as usual, but gave the ball away cheaply at times.\n\nTrent Alexander-Arnold - 5\n\nTwo games in, the TAA midfield experiment has not worked. A few heavy touches early on and next to nothing in terms of creativity with his wonderful long-range skillset. Hooked just after half-time, it'd be a surprise if he started against Slovenia.\n\nBukayo Saka - 6\n\nShowed flashes, but it was more neat and tidy from the Arsenal winger as opposed to the end product of the first match. Notable, too, that he was substituted on 70 minutes.\n\nJude Bellingham - 6\n\nGiven his talismanic performance against Serbia, a strangely uninfluential day for England's No 10 in Frankfurt. Kept looking for the ball until the end and set up Watkins well late on, but a day of frustration for Bellingham.\n\nPhil Foden - 6\n\nLivelier than his anonymous opening game performance. Lovely footwork carved out a chance single-handedly early on but the Premier League player of the season skewed his shot wide. Similarly danced through the Danish midfield just before half-time but shot weakly, when he should have played in Kane, and hit the post in the second-half. Better.\n\nHarry Kane - 7\n\nOff the mark at Euro 2024 with a typical cool finish from the break of the ball in the box, goal No 64 for the Three Lions, but did give the ball away very cheaply in his own half, with Denmark equalising seconds later. Other than his goal, again struggled to get into the game and nothing said that more than the skipper being substituted with 20 minutes to go.\n\nBooked soon after coming on for a rash challenge and didn't seem up to speed at times.\n\nOllie Watkins - 7\n\nBrilliant run in behind early on; pace which may well be utilised more going forward.\n\nA tad more involved than Eze, but didn't quite have the time to link-up effectively with Walker down the right.", "source": {"uri": "ca.sports.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo Sports Canada"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": 'Harry wasn't affecting the game at all, he was coming too deep and condensing the play.'\n\nShearer later added that Southgate needs to inject pace into the side if he is to get the best out of England's all-time record goalscorer.\n\nShearer said: 'I mentioned it but when I go into my 30s and lost half a yard of pace I needed legs around me, I needed pace around me.\n\n'I could still hold the ball up, I still had a good touch, I could still head it and score goals. The one thing I couldn't constantly do was run in behind. He needs players in and around him.\n\n'That's why I'd have Gordon in the team because he has the energy to run in behind and get up near him.\n\n'When Foden is there he want to play tight and get in the No.10 role, like Harry Kane does. Someone else can do it alongside him.\n\n'That's why I retired I couldn't do it for both England and Newcastle. I have to say that so far, I don't know if our own fans have noticed, it is like playing at home\", H\u00f8jbjerg said.\n\nThe draw leaves Denmark in second place in Group C, while England are on top after Slovenia's 1-1 draw with Serbia earlier.\n\n\"I can't say we are disappointed, because we felt good\", Denmark coach Kasper Hjulmand said, adding that they had felt more disappointed after their opening draw with Slovenia.\n\n\"Today we showed how we really play, with fire,\" he said. \"I thought we could win.\"\n\nEngland took the lead in the 18th minute through Harry Kane, but the Danes capitalised on England's sloppy play in the 34th minute when Morten Hjulmand fired in a rocket from about 30 yards that crashed in off the post to equalise.\n\nDenmark then held on to deny Gareth Southgate's side the chance to become the first England team to win their two opening games at a European Championships.\n\n\"We were well-prepared\", H\u00f8jbjerg said, adding that his side's substitutions had given them energy late on.\n\nHjulmand in turn praised H\u00f8jbjerg: \"He roars, he drives the ball, he sends signals, he sends signals to the stadium. This is Pierre at his best.\"\n\nDenmark take on Serbia in their final group game on Tuesday, while England face Slovenia.", "source": {"uri": "channelnewsasia.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8187637749", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:58:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:58:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:56:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://www.belfasttelegraph.co.uk/news/viral/english-fan-and-danish-wife-still-alive-after-1-1-draw-at-euros/a1025113553.html", "title": "English fan and Danish wife 'still alive' after 1-1 draw at Euros", "body": "Michael Wild, 74, from Colesbourne, Gloucestershire, and wife Joan watched England draw 1-1 with Denmark in Frankfurt, Germany, missing the chance to top their European Championship group with a game to spare.\n\nThe England supporter and his Denmark-supporting wife sat in their front room together to watch the game, each displaying opposing reactions but joked they remain on good terms.\n\nMr Wild told the PA news agency: \"We're all fine. We're still alive and nobody's fallen out.\n\n\"We watched it at home sitting next to each other in adjacent chairs making our own comments as we went along.\n\n\"It was interesting listening to comments of 'that was good' or 'that was awful' coming out at the same time.\"\n\nAsked about his thoughts moments after the match, he added: \"My reaction was 'oh dear' and the wife's reaction was 'oh great' and I've been getting messages (from family) of 'you were rubbish'.\n\nThe football fan predicted watching England face Denmark would be \"a bit of fun\" but admits his wife is \"a lot happier than I am\". Both agreed \"Denmark probably deserved to win it and England was pretty poor\".\n\nMrs Wild waved the Danish flag post-match while Mr Wild looked \"particularly glum\" on his living room chair but said a trip to his local pub helped his mood.\n\n\"Best thing to do is come and relax over a quiet pint and a cigar at the garden of my local pub,\" he said.\n\nMr Wild said the 1-1 outcome was not as he expected but agreed to offer his support for both England and Denmark throughout the tournament.\n\n\"It was not what I'd expected or it's not what I'd hoped for, but now I can go through the rest of the tournament quite happily supporting Denmark when they play and England when they play and hopefully they won't meet each other again,\" the England supporter said.\n\nBefore the match, Mr Wild predicted England would win 2-1 but described their performance on Thursday as \"appalling\".\n\n\"I thought it was a pretty appalling performance but it's no different than what we've seen over the last few games,\" he said.\n\n\"Harry Kane's goal was Harry Kane doing what Harry Kane does best. In a 90-minute game, if you only give him one opportunity don't expect miracles.\n\n\"I thought his goal was great, somewhat fortuitous, but well taken.\"\n\nHe also feels England manager Gareth Southgate could do more to \"move England forward\".\n\n\"Not that I know anything at all about football tactics but I don't think Southgate has got the balance at all right. The midfield seems to be a non-entity,\" he said.\n\n\"My own personal view is he's been in the role for eight years and he hasn't moved England forward.\"\n\nMr Wild described the group-stage game as somewhat poignant as it came 40 years after the Danes beat England in a Euro 1984 qualifying match at Wembley.\n\nMr and Mrs Wild recalled being on their honeymoon in France during the football tournament.\n\nNow, 40 years on, the couple watched as England drew 1-1 against Denmark in a result Mr Wild did not expect.\n\nHe joked: \"At the end of the day, it's a sport and it's a bit of fun. {"uri": "8181718011", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-17", "time": "10:38:46", "dateTime": "2024-06-17T10:38:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-17T10:37:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4862745106220245, "url": "https://www.football365.com/news/carragher-fears-southgate-compromise-england-kane-turning-him-into-haaland-man-city", "title": "England 'will not win Euro 2024' as Southgate reduces Kane to 'one-dimensional' Haaland role?", "body": "Liverpool legend Jamie Carragher has criticised England manager Gareth Southgate for 'reinventing Harry Kane as Erling Haaland'. As if that's a bad thing.\n\nCarragher obviously says this knowing that Kane has more to his game than Haaland, but you know, it's hardly going to hurt England if they have a ridiculously prolific goalscorer up front.\n\nThe former Tottenham striker was very uninvolved in the Three Lions' Euro 2024 opener against Serbia, with Jude Bellingham's 13th-minute header enough to secure the three points.\n\nSome are concerned by Kane's lack of involvement but it could be a blessing in disguise having been criticised for dropping too deep to get involved for England.\n\nMORE ON ENGLAND FROM F365\n\n\ud83d\udc49 England fans, 10 German Bombers and the glimpse into a thick slice of our culture\n\n\ud83d\udc49 Jude Bellingham's England (just) beat Serbia: 16 Conclusions on an unnecessarily nervy opener\n\nUnfortunately for the player, he can't have it both ways. He actually plays up front and gets criticised. That's punditry for you. Double-edged swords everywhere.\n\nIt is fair to be unimpressed by Kane's performance vs Serbia on Sunday and Carragher believes Southgate using him more as a poacher \"reduces his effectiveness by 50 per cent\".\n\n\"Kane had only two touches in the entire first half against Serbia - England will not win the Euros if that continues,\" the former Three Lions centre-back wrote in his Telegraph column.\n\n\"Of all Gareth Southgate's strategies for winning the Euros, few anticipated Harry Kane being reinvented as Erling Haaland.\n\n\"On the surface that sounds like a great plan for the country and for any striker. The role is specific and in some respects old-school; to play as much as possible on the shoulder of the last defender, stay on the fringe of the action as the midfielders assume all the creative responsibilities, patiently awaiting one moment to strike.\n\n\"The problem with a player of Kane's many abilities is that it reduces his effectiveness by 50 per cent. Kane is a multi-tasking, modern centre-forward who was reduced to one-dimension during the 1-0 win over Serbia.\n\n\"If Southgate persists with the same system for the rest of the tournament, his No 9 will be heavily compromised. Possibly too much. Having come into the Euros with a Phil Foden conundrum, after one game Southgate has a Kane one.\n\n\"In the first half, Kane registered just two touches of the ball. For a player of his class, that is deeply worrying.\n\n\"By full time that had risen to 24, showing that he was more involved in the second half - ironic given that England were less dominant in possession. There is a tactical curiosity that when England played well, Kane was not involved at all. When they didn't, he nearly scored and had more possession.\"\n\nCarragher continued: \"Kane is at his best when he is surrounded by pace. At the last three international tournaments, he liked to drop deep and supply passes to rapid wide strikers like Bukayo Saka and Raheem Sterling, or (when selected) Marcus Rashford.\n\n\"Even when England were in control during the first 30 minutes against Serbia, Saka was the only attacker running beyond the defence. He was brilliant, but there was too much responsibility on him to make those runs.\n\n\"The lack of pace hurt England the longer the game progressed, so it was surprising Anthony Gordon was not introduced. There is also an argument that Ollie Watkins should have replaced Kane for the last 20 minutes because he is quicker and could have freshened it up physically.\n\n\"True, Kane nearly had his reward when he forced an impressive save on 77 minutes. Like Haaland, interpretations of whether he played well or not become defined by such opportunities.\"\n\n\ud83d\udce3 TO THE COMMENTS! Is this version of Harry Kane hurting or harming England? Join the debate here.\n\nIndeed, Carragher believes England's lack of pace hurts the team with \"too much responsibility\" on Bukayo Saka on the right wing.\n\n\"I have always distinguished the best centre-forwards between great players and great goalscorers,\" he added. \"Haaland is a great scorer. Kane is a great player who scores lots of goals.\n\n\"The reason he is world class is because he does not need to score to have an impact on a game. At his best, he is a goalscoring No 9, a false 9 and a creative No 10.\n\n\"Redefining him as a poacher to accommodate so many team-mates who want to occupy the deep, No 10 position will be the most contentious decision Southgate makes if England are unsuccessful.\"", "source": {"uri": "football365.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Football News -"}, "authors": [{"uri": "jason_soutar@football365.com", "name": "Jason Soutar", "type": "author", "isAgency": false}], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Erling_Haaland", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"uri": "2024-06-396283781", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "18:28:12", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T18:28:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T18:27:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/sport/football/england-denmark-player-ratings-jude-bellingham-euro-2024-3123618", "title": "England vs Denmark player ratings: Bellingham scores 4/10 in drab Euro 2024 draw", "body": "For the third time in successive major tournaments under Gareth Southgate they served up thin gruel in their second game. A 1-1 draw keeps them top of Group C but the boos that rang out from the travelling England supporters told their own story - this was far from good enough.\n\nAfter Harry Kane opened the scoring with a smart close range finish they were second best to Denmark for the rest of the half. Morten Hjulmand's superb long range drive was the least they deserved.\n\nA soporific second half was evenly matched as Southgate rolled the dice with four substitutions to no avail. This result as good as books a last 16 place but unless they improve dramatically, they won't go much further than that.\n\nThe sight of Pickford howling at his back four with England under the cosh will live long in the memory. Clearly felt exposed and who could blame him? Beaten from long range again and distribution iffy.\n\nKieran Trippier - 6/10\n\nIt needed all of his tournament experience to guide England through this one. Luke Shaw might return for the big ones but Trippier has not let anyone down as his understudy.\n\nMarc Guehi - 6/10\n\nYou sometimes forget he's new to this. As England flailed he held the line - and his recovery tackle after Rice sold him short preserved this point.\n\nJohn Stones - 5/10\n\nEngland's most experienced defender but couldn't get a foothold on this one. Didn't help that he was offered virtually zero cover by a midfield that was missing in action.\n\nKyle Walker - 6/10\n\nThe omens weren't great when he slipped in the first minute and had to change his boots. Set up Kane for the opener with a brilliant blindside run but after it was mostly defensive work.\n\nJude Bellingham - 4/10\n\nThis was oh-so-quiet from England's diamond as Denmark did a number on him. Misplaced passes, mistimed tackles, running into cul-de-sacs - by the end his frustration was palpable.\n\nDeclan Rice - 5/10\n\nSurvived Southgate's flurry of substitutions but make no mistake he was every bit as culpable for England's midfield mess. That short pass for Guehi with ten minutes to go was nearly terminal.\n\nTrent Alexander-Arnold - 4/10\n\nIt's not his fault, you know. In a tournament of Toni Kroos, giving a man who plays his club football with distinction at right-back the midfield metronome role was never going to work. Gave it away far too much.\n\nBukayo Saka - 6/10\n\nThere was a brief 15 minute spell when he sparkled and England looked dangerous but otherwise Denmark's high line snuffed out his threat. So frustrating his threat couldn't be harnessed.\n\nPhil Foden - 7/10\n\nNever, ever write off a talent like Foden. As England retreated he did more than anyone to try and drag them back into the game and cracked the post with their best second half effort.\n\nHarry Kane - 6/10\n\nHis 13th goal in a major tournament but not a vintage afternoon. He dropped too deep to be a sustained menace and it was his loose pass that was punished for the Denmark leveller.\n\nRestored a bit of balance in midfield when he came on, at least stemming the red tide. Harsh yellow card meant he was playing on the edge but did that well. Will start against Slovenia.\n\nJarrod Bowen - 5/10\n\nWill he come into Southgate's thinking next week? Looked to get into the right spaces when he came on but this was a more difficult assignment than troubling the Serbs.\n\nEberechi Eze - 5/10\n\nHailed as one of England's \"finishers\" but couldn't get into the game when he came on. Hopefully that isn't the sum total of his contribution to the tournament.\n\nOllie Watkins - 5/10\n\nOne brilliant run that summoned a super save from Kasper Schmeichel was almost enough to make his introduction inspired. Still has questions to answer at this level.", "source": {"uri": "inews.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "inews.co.uk"}, "authors": [{"uri": "mark_douglas@inews.co.uk", "name": "Mark Douglas", {"uri": "8187585661", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:07:40", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:07:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:06:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "url": "https://www.the42.ie/england-denmark-talking-point-6415271-Jun2024/", "title": "Can England win the Euros by playing like Martin O'Neill's Ireland?", "body": "Gareth Southgate's men flattered to deceive against Denmark today. Paul Fennessy\n\nBEFORE Euro 2024 began, England were the favourite of most bookmakers to triumph.\n\nIt's hard to remember a previous example of when the most hotly-tipped team to win a major tournament looked so technically limited.\n\nThe irony is that today's 1-1 draw with Denmark all but assures the Three Lions' place in the knockout stages, but the downcast mood and fans booing at full-time told a different story.\n\nThe frequent joke about Martin O'Neill's Ireland was that they scored \"too early\".\n\nMany times over the years, particularly under O'Neill, Ireland went ahead in games and tried to batten down the hatches, consequently always getting overrun by technically superior teams like Georgia.\n\nIt happened during the nadir of O'Neill's Ireland reign, a 5-1 defeat by Denmark, when a Shane Duffy goal after six minutes had given his side false hope.\n\nEngland were not quite as bad as the Boys in Green that night, but with better players, they have been deploying a similar gameplan for years.\n\nIt was true of their 2018 World Cup semi-final defeat against Croatia when Kieran Trippier's free-kick put them ahead after five minutes only to lose 2-1.\n\nIt was also the case in the Euro 2020 final at Wembley, when Luke Shaw scored after two minutes only for the Italians to dominate for much of the remaining contest before winning on penalties.\n\nAnd it was evident against Serbia the other night when Gareth Southgate's side more or less shut up shop after Jude Bellingham's 13th-minute opener.\n\nAnd there was another repeat showing this afternoon.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe biggest difference between the Serbia and Denmark games was the latter played with more self-belief.\n\nIn the first 13 minutes especially, you got the sense the Serbs had bought into the England hype and lacked any real conviction in attack, struggling to trouble the English defence despite dominating the play.\n\nSerbia coach Dragan Stojkovic acknowledged as much afterwards.\n\n\"Against England we started playing with too much respect for them, like they came from another planet,\" he said.\n\n\"It should not be like that. We've played better against them later in the match and that's how we'll play against Slovenia.\"\n\nSerbia arguably deserved a draw on the balance of play, and similarly today, Denmark could easily have turned a point into three.\n\nHowever, Kasper Hjulmand's side looked happy enough with the result. Would they have substituted Christian Eriksen and goalscorer Morten Hjulmand with just over 10 minutes remaining in a knockout game?\n\nThey were the technically superior, well-organised team and ended the game much stronger.\n\nGareth Southgate's men, by contrast, looked bereft of ideas and were reduced to constantly knocking hopeful balls up the pitch -- a sure sign that a team has lost faith in its gameplan assuming there was a clear one to begin with.\n\nDeclan Rice might have been forgiven for feeling like he was back playing for O'Neill's Ireland, for whom he won three caps in 2018 (a 1-0 loss to Turkey in the game directly after the Denmark mauling, a 2-0 defeat by France and a 2-1 win over USA).\n\nRice's former teammate James McClean received plenty of flak online for claiming the Arsenal star is overrated and not world class.\n\n\"I don't think he gets in the Man City side ahead of Rodri,\" the ex-Ireland international added. \"I know Toni Kross is now retiring, but to me Toni Kroos is world-class. He dictates the game, Rodri dictates the game, I don't think Declan Rice does that.\"\n\nThe comments were harsh but there is some truth to them.\n\nRice is brilliant at many aspects of the game. Physically, there are few superior players at the elite level. But technically, he is somewhat limited, struggles on the half-turn, and is usually happy to play the ball backwards or sideways -- these flaws tend to be especially notable at major tournaments, where the football is much slower and more methodical compared with the Premier League.\n\nAt Arsenal, he plays alongside Jorginho and Martin Odegaard, two players who can compensate for Rice's deficiencies.\n\nSouthgate was hoping Trent Alexander Arnold could do the same for England.\n\nYet the Liverpool star has been substituted relatively early in both group games for the more industrious Conor Gallagher.\n\nBut the midfield remained England's biggest problem for much of the 90 minutes, so Southgate's bold decision to take off his attacking trio of Harry Kane, Bukayo Saka and Phil Foden felt a little irrelevant.\n\nIt was not addressing the main problem, which continued, as Ollie Watkins, Jarrod Bowen and Eberechi Eze were similarly isolated owing to the midfield's inability to knit the play together with the likes of Eriksen, Hjulmand and the excellent Pierre-Emile H\u00f8jbjerg winning the battle in that area of the pitch.\n\nEngland should not be written off based on today's game.\n\nInterestingly, their defence, which some critics cited as their biggest weakness going into the tournament, has been the most impressive aspect of the opening two games.\n\nAnd competency in this position is invariably what wins team's tournaments -- Spain won all their knockout games 1-0 at the 2010 World Cup and France kept clean sheets at four out of seven games on their way to glory in 2018.\n\nYet at the moment, the solid-looking backline coupled with a couple of individual players capable of producing a moment of magic out of nothing is all Southgate is relying on.\n\nTheir midfield has not been good enough for this level and those people who bought into the hype and backed England to end 58 years of hurt surely have second thoughts now.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8187581492", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-20", "time": "19:04:06", "dateTime": "2024-06-20T19:04:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-20T19:02:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "url": "https://www.101greatgoals.com/news/euro-2024-eriksen/", "title": "Euro 2024: 'Denmark deserved to win' - Eriksen", "body": "Christian Eriksen thinks Denmark deserved to beat England in Thursday night's Group C showdown in Frankfurt.\n\nThe Danes battled back after falling behind to a Harry Kane opener and Morten Hjulmand's thunderbolt ensured a share of the points and meant all four teams could still qualify for the Round of 16 going into Tuesday's final matches.\n\n\"We felt like if there was a team who deserved to win, it was us,\" Eriksen told BBC Sport. \"We didn't get the win but for us it was a better game than (Sunday's 1-1 draw against Slovenia).\n\n\"I don't think England surprised us in any way. We know they have exceptional players. I think we hurt them with the chances we had in the game - I think we should have won instead of getting a draw.\n\n\"(Harry Kane) is always around in the box and gets all the ugly goals, but to come back with a perfect strike from Morten kept us in the game, gave us a bit of belief afterwards, it's just unfortunate we didn't take the belief through to score more goals.\"\n\nDenmark face Serbia on against Denmark, Spain set to battle Italy for last 16 place", "body": "Jude Bellingham failed to inspire England in a disappointing 1-1 draw against Denmark\n\nEngland struggled to show their credentials to win Euro 2024 in a 1-1 draw with Denmark that left them with work to do to reach the last 16, while Spain and Italy will battle it out to reach the knockout stages later on Thursday.\n\nVictory for England in Frankfurt would have booked their place in the next round as Group C winners.\n\nHowever, an underwhelming performance by Gareth Southgate's men leaves more questions over their quest to becoming European champions for the first time.\n\nIn a rematch of the Euro 2020 semi-final won by England, it was Southgate's men who got off to a perfect start when Harry Kane slotted home after Kyle Walker caught Danish defender Victor Kristiansen napping.\n\nDenmark, though, were well worthy of at least a point and got it thanks to a spectacular strike by Morten Hjulmand before half-time.\n\nPhil Foden hit the post for England and Denmark's Andreas Christensen came close to a late winner in the second half.\n\nBut a share of the spoils leaves it all to play for in the final games of Group C on Tuesday.\n\nEarlier, Luka Jovic snatched a point for Serbia in the 95th minute to hold Slovenia 1-1.\n\nZan Karnicnik headed Slovenia in front 21 minutes from time.\n\nBut Serbia kept their fate of reaching the last 16 in their own hands when AC Milan striker Jovic headed in a corner with virtually the last action of the game.\n\nEngland top the group on four points, two clear of Denmark and Slovenia, and just need a draw when they face Slovenia in Cologne to qualify.\n\n- Spain, Italy go for last 16 -\n\nGelsenkirchen plays host to one of the most-highly anticipated clashes of the group stage later as the winners of three of the last four Euros go head-to-head.\n\nSpain's mix of precocious youth and experience shone in a dazzling 3-0 win over World Cup semi-finalists Croatia to get their campaign off to a flying start.\n\nMore from this section Charlie Kirk says he 'prays' for Donald Trump's protection US: Point Fire Rages In Sonoma County, Evacuation Orders Issued 2 Colorado Supreme Court to hear arguments in transgender cake case\n\nItaly had to fight back after conceding the fastest goal in the competition's history to beat Albania 2-1.\n\nVictory for either side will guarantee progress to the knockout stages as group winners and avoid the possibility of facing England in the quarter-finals.\n\nThe countries have met in each of the last four Euros - Italy emerging victorious in the last two after Spain won on their route to glory at Euro 2008 and 2012.\n\n\"The players will understand when they get to my age that they'll want to have stories to tell,\" said Italy coach Luciano Spalletti.\n\n\"This is one of those matches that gives them the chance to create that story.\"\n\nSpain's more direct style was notable in their victory over Croatia as La Roja won comfortably despite having less possession than their opponents for the first time in 136 competitive matches dating back 16 years.\n\n\"It's almost like we're looking in a mirror actually,\" said Spain coach Luis de la Fuente of the sides' similar styles.\n\n\"We are a growing, developing team which is working on cohesion and consistency and so are they. I think it will be a very high quality match.\"\n\n- Masked Mbappe -\n\nFrance take on the Netherlands in one of the other marquee games of the group stage on Friday.\n\nKylian Mbappe's participation in that match in Leipzig remains uncertain after the France captain broke his nose in Les Bleus' opening 1-0 win over Austria.\n\nHowever, Didier Deschamps is hopeful of having Real Madrid's new signing available after Mbappe trained in a mask inspired by the colours of the French flag on Thursday.\n\n\"Things are progressing in the right direction enough for us to try to have him available {"uri": "8185695221", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-06-19", "time": "17:08:17", "dateTime": "2024-06-19T17:08:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-06-19T17:03:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4549019634723663, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13547809/Denmark-dreaming-glory-ahead-England-showdown.html", "title": "Denmark still dreaming of glory ahead of England showdown", "body": "By Nick Said\n\nFRANKFURT, Germany, June 19 (Reuters) - Denmark have long lost the bitter taste of defeat from three years ago and are not fuelled by thoughts of revenge as they face England in European Championship Group C on Thursday in search of a repeat of their 1992 continental triumph.\n\nThe Danes were furious following a 2-1 Euro 2020 semi-final loss to England at Wembley after a spot-kick awarded to the hosts in extra-time led to Harry Kane's winner as he knocked in the rebound after his initial effort was saved.\n\nDenmark coach Kasper Hjulmand described it at the time as a \"penalty which should not have been a penalty\".\n\n\"It took me a while to digest it. I carried it for a while,\" he told reporters on Wednesday. \"Those kinds of defeats make us learn and grow, but they also make you believe you can do it, because we were so close (to a final).\"\n\nDenmark were disappointed they let a lead slip in a 1-1 draw with Slovenia in their Group C opener, and Hjulmand says there are no thoughts of settling for a point against one of the tournament favourites.\n\n\"We are going to go out with the mindset to win the game,\" he said. \"We are going to be fighting for the ball, England have a lot of quality and are good at controlling possession.\n\n\"We have had some good results against England when we had control over the ball. So we are going to try do what we are best at. But nothing is gifted, we have fight for it.\"\n\nCaptain Simon Kjaer will be fit to start if selected.\n\n\"He could play, he has been doing better. He had a good training session and his numbers look good,\" Hjulmand said.\n\nDenmark's former Leicester City goalkeeper Kasper Schmeichel, whose father Peter lifted the European Championship in 1992, is full of praise for Thursday\u00b4s opponents.\n\n\"They were a world-class side when they made the final (in 2021) and when you look at the additions that have come in and the experience they have gained, I think this is the best England team since I started watching them,\" Kasper Schmeichel said.\n\n\"I don\u00b4t think anyone comes to the Euros without dreaming of a gold medal. We have done it before as a country, my generation was inspired by that win in 1992.\n\n\"The standards (to win it) are high and that is how it should be. But if you don\u00b4t have dreams, life is not fun.\"\n\n(Reporting by Nick Said, editing by Ed Osmond)", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"},
